However, plain error review remains available for such a challenge, despite a deficient objection. United States v. Diaz, 300 F.3d 66 (1st Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Every purpose for which evidence is admissible must be articulated when counsel makes an offer of proof. Tate v. Robbins & Myers, Inc., 790 F.2d 10 (1st Cir. 1986); Reese v. Mercury Marine Div. of Brunswick Corp., 793 F.2d 1416 (5th Cir. 1986).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 403 balancing not explicitly required unless objection is made under that rule. United States v. Long, 574 F.2d 761 (3d Cir. 1978).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        General Objections

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where counsel merely stated Id object concerning the general prospect of a witnesss testimony, the basis for objection was not clear based on the context and counsel subsequently failed to raise any objection when the witness was eventually called to the stand, counsel failed to properly object to the witnesss testimony for purposes of Rule 103. United States v. Jean-Guerrier, 666 F.3d 1087 (8th Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        General objection to questions about defendants knowledge of alleged co-conspirators criminal record does not require specific grounds, so appeal is based on harmless, not plain, error doctrine. United States v. Cudlitz, 72 F.3d 992 (1st Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An objection to inconsistent or unfair rulings was not a sufficiently specific ground upon which to obtain reversal on appeal. Walters v. Monarch Life Ins. Co., 57 F.3d 899 (1st Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Motion for mistrial at close of government case based on incorrect objection to testimony by a prosecution witness does not preserve issue for appeal. United States v. Rivera, 43 F.3d 1291 (9th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 25 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A general objection to relevancy was insufficient to preserve an objection based on improper reference to a settlement. Calcasieu Marine Natl Bank v. Grant, 943 F.2d 1453 (5th Cir. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        General relevancy objections may not be sufficient to preserve claims under other Article IV (relevancy) rules. Bryant v. Conrail Corp., 672 F.2d 217 (1st Cir. 1982).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Offers of Proof

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Established Doctrine

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A formal offer of proof is not required under Rule 103(a), but the substance of the evidence, what it will show, and the grounds for admissibility must be made known to the court or be apparent from the context. United States v. Ganier, 468 F.3d 920 (6th Cir. 2006); United States v. Henderson, 409 F.3d 1293 (11th Cir. 2005); Badami v. Flood, 214 F.3d 994 (8th Cir. 2000); United States v. Martinez, 776 F.2d 1481 (10th Cir. 1985); United States v. Wright, 783 F.2d 1091 (D.C. Cir. 1986); McQuaig v. McCoy, 806 F.2d 1298 (5th Cir. 1987); United States v. Sweiss, 814 F.2d 1208 (7th Cir. 1987); Strong v. Mercantile Trust Co., N.A., 816 F.2d 429 (8th Cir. 1987); Coursen v. A.H. Robins Co., 764 F.2d 1329 (9th Cir. 1985).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court cannot refuse to hear a partys proffer of proof. Moss v. Ole S. Real Estate, Inc., 933 F.2d 1300 (5th Cir. 1991); State v. Flohr, 301 N.W.2d 367 (N.D. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Case Applications

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An offer of proof, as required to preserve a claim of wrongfully excluded evidence for purposes of appeal under Rule 103(a)(2), is provided to inform the court and opposing counsel of the substance of the excluded evidence and to provide the appellate court with a record sufficient to allow it to determine if the exclusion was erroneous. United States v. Henley, 766 F.3d 893 (8th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The requirement under Rule 103(a)(2) that an offer of proof be made in order to preserve a claim of wrongfully excluded evidence for appeal is essential in two ways. First, it gives the trial judge the information needed to make an informed ruling. Judges are not mind readers, and even the most prepared judge cannot possibly know as much about a partys case (and strategy) as the lawyer who is trying it. Thus, when the relevance of a particular line of questioning is not self-evident, an explanation of what the anticipated answers will be and how those answers advance the partys theory of the case is critical. Second, without that explanation there is no way for a reviewing court to determine whether excluding the evidence was prejudicial. Wilson v. City of Chicago, 758 F.3d 875 (7th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An offer of proof, required by Rule 103(a)(2) to preserve an objection based on a claim of wrongfully excluded evidence, is essential because it gives the trial judge the information needed to make an informed ruling. Even the most prepared judge cannot possibly know as much about a partys case (and strategy) as the lawyer who is trying it. Thus, a party cannot offer testimony for one reason and later complain that it should have been admitted for another reason, because to do so defeats the purpose of requiring an offer of proof. McCarthy v. Fuller, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 130848 (S.D. Ind. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An offer of proof, as contemplated under Rule 103, can take the form of a summary, because Rule 103(b) leaves the form of offer within the discretion of the trial court. Probably the most common method of making an offer of proof of testimonial evidence is the avowal of counselsometimes called an attorney offer of proof, where counsel simply states to the judge, with reasonable specificity, what he or she anticipates the witnesss testimony will be. Alternatively, to make a proffer, counsel mayin the courts discretionput the witness on the stand, outside the presence of the jury, and elicit responses in a question-and-answer format before the judge. Moore v. City of Clarksville, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 123724 (M.D. Tenn. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 103(a)(2), which requires an offer of proof to preserve an objection to a ruling excluding evidence, compels the conclusion that, when challenging an exclusionary ruling, the

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 26 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        aggrieved party must show that the substance of the evidence sought to be introduced was made known to the court by offer or was apparent from the context within which questions were asked. United States v. Rodriguez-Velez, 597 F.3d 32 (1st Cir. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The offer-of-proof requirement does not apply directly to administrative proceedings, yet its substance still governs because courts do not set aside agencies decisions unless mistakes cause prejudice, and prejudice cannot be ascertained without an offer of proof or some substitute. Chakir v. Gonzales, 466 F.3d 563 (7th Cir. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a criminal case, defendant made a proffer sufficient under Rule 103 to preserve objection to the trial courts limitations of testimony he sought to admit where the record indicated that defense counsel held a lengthy discussion with the district court in which he described such testimony and the three groups of witnesses that he intended to call to provide it. United States v. Akpan, 407 F.3d 360 (5th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Trial counsel made a sufficient, although scant offer of proof when he stated that certain accident reports formed the basis of the expert opinions testimony. Even though a formal proffer was not made, this was enough to preserve on appeal the issue of whether the district judges refusal to admit the accident reports was proper. Guy v. Crown Equip. Corp., 394 F.3d 320 (5th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The purpose of an offer of proof under Rule 103 is to make an adequate record for the appellate court to rule on. Counsel adequately apprised the district court of the plaintiffs proffer by eliciting testimony from an expert about the experts training and the purpose of the experts inspection of a vehicle involved in the accident at issue. Sih v. United States, 90 F. Appx 940 (7th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An oral proffer, provided that it adequately describes to the court the substance of the evidence, may be sufficient to preserve an issue for appeal. United States v. Brown, 303 F.3d 582 (5th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Offers of proof must be on the record to preserve appeal and thus an unrecorded motion in limine to exclude testimony does not preserve the issue for appeal. Dupre v. Fru-Con Engg, Inc., 112 F.3d 329 (8th Cir. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testimony expected must be set forth to preserve error in excluding a witness. United States v. Jackson, 208 F.3d 633 (7th Cir. 2000); Inselman v. S&J Operating Co., 44 F.3d 894 (10th Cir. 1995); Helmick v. Smith, 1995 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 6909 (W.D. Mich. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An offer of proof has often been held excused when, in the circumstances, it would be futile, such as where the district court has expressly refused to permit additional evidence on a defined topic. United States v. Bell Petroleum Servs., Inc., 64 F.3d 202 (5th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Failure to make offer of proof regarding witness testimony precludes review because appeals court has no way of determining whether a substantial right was affected by the ruling excluding the witness. Isr. Travel Advisory Serv., Inc. v. Isr. Identity Tours, Inc., 61 F.3d 1250 (7th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The failure to make an offer of proof may bar review, since the proponent must show in some fashion the substance of the proposed testimony. Stockstill v. Shell Oil Co., 3 F.3d 868 (5th Cir. 1993).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Counsel must articulate the theory of an evidentiary offer, especially when the proof is subject to a hearsay objection and alternative purposes for admission may be present. Maddox v. Patterson, 905 F.2d 1178 (8th Cir. 1990).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Failure to make offer of proof showing substance of allegedly inconsistent statements sought to be admitted generally precludes appeal of district courts refusal to admit such statements. United States v. Dennis, 843 F.2d 652 (2d Cir. 1988); United States v. Leisure, 844 F.2d 1347 (8th Cir. 1988).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An offer of proof should set forth the evidentiary theories on which admissibility is predicated. Reese v. Mercury Marine Div. of Brunswick Corp., 793 F.2d 1416 (5th Cir. 1986); United States v. Wright, 783 F.2d 1091 (D.C. Cir. 1986).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Offer of proof must be made where cross-examination is restricted. Saltzman v. Fullerton Metals Co., 661 F.2d 647 (7th Cir. 1981); United States v. Lavallie, 666 F.2d 1217 (8th Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 27 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Court may require offer of proof by testimony or written statement where needed to make clear record. Fid. Sav. & Loan v. Aetna, 647 F.2d 933 (9th Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Offer of proof must be made on impeachment evidence as well as direct. United States v. Winkle, 587 F.2d 705 (5th Cir. 1979).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The court reporter should record offers of proof. United States v. Johnson, 542 F.2d 230 (5th Cir. 1976).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Exclusion of the jury is proper when hearing foundation or offer of proof. In re McConnell, 370 U.S. 230 (U.S. 1962); Pottstape Assocs. v. Eastman Kodak Co., 537 F.2d 751 (3d Cir. 1976).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Multiparty Cases

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In multiparty cases, in some courts each need not join in objection or offer of proof to benefit from it. Howard v. Gonzales, 658 F.2d 352 (5th Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Unnecessary ObjectionsFutility

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Futility of objection, if clear, may excuse silence and permit appellate review. United States v. Rivera, 513 F.2d 519 (2d Cir. 1975).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Continuing Objections

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Although a continuing objection is permissible under Rule 103, continuing objections generally are considered inappropriate for preserving error on appeal under Rule 403. United States v. McVeigh, 153 F.3d 1166 (10th Cir. 1998).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Continuing objections or limiting instructions must be requested to preserve error. United States v. Potter, 616 F.2d 384 (9th Cir. 1979).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Continuing objections or limiting instructions generally must be specified with the court. United States v. Semak, 536 F.2d 1141 (6th Cir. 1976); United States v. Barnes, 586 F.2d 1052 (5th Cir. 1978).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In Limine Rulings: Definitiveness Issues

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Established Doctrine

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In making preliminary determinations regarding the existence of a privilege under Rule 104, a district court is not bound by the hearsay rule. Muro v. Target Corp., 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 81776 (N.D. Ill. 2007).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A criminal defendant must testify at trial in order to obtain appellate review of a trial court in limine ruling allowing use of a prior conviction to impeach credibility. Luce v. United States, 469 U.S. 38 (U.S. 1984).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Case Applications

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        To preserve an issue for appeal, Rule 103(a)(1) requires that counsel make a timely objection or motion to strike and state the specific ground, unless it was apparent from the context. A terse motion in limine that fails to identify exactly what evidence is objected to or on what grounds the motion relies is not specific enough to meet the requirements of this rule. United States v. Marr, 760 F.3d 733 (7th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 103(b) does not purport to answer the question whether a party who objects to evidence that the court finds admissible in a definitive ruling, and who then offers the same or similar evidence to remove the sting of its anticipated prejudicial effect, thereby waives the right to appeal the trial courts ruling on its objection. The Fifth Circuit holds that by introducing such evidence, a litigant waives its right to appeal the district courts denial of its earlier motion in limine to exclude it. Blessey Marine Servs. v. Jeffboat, L.L.C., 2014 U.S. App. LEXIS 21733 (5th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 28 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A pretrial motion in limine to exclude evidence will not always preserve an objection for appellate review, but consistent with Rule 103(b), it may do so when the issue (1) is fairly presented to the district court, (2) is the type of issue that can be finally decided in a pretrial hearing, and (3) is ruled upon without equivocation by the trial judge. United States v. Powers, 578 F. Appx 763 (10th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        If the trial court has made an explicit and definitive ruling on the record of the evidentiary issues to be decided and has not indicated that the ruling is conditioned upon any other circumstances or evidence, then counsel need not renew the objection at the time the evidence is offered (or would have been offered but for an exclusionary ruling) in order to preserve the error for appeal, by operation of Rule 103(b). However, if the courts ruling is in any way qualified or conditional, the burden is on counsel to raise objection to preserve error. Butcher v. Bryson, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 125268 (M.D. Tenn. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Motions in limine are authorized, consistent with the language in Rule 103(d) indicating that a trial should be conducted so as to prevent inadmissible evidence from being suggested to the jury by any means. Allstate Prop. & Cas. Ins. Co. v. Mercury Plastics, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 128738 (D. Nev. 2014); Gonzales v. Shotgun Nev. Invs., LLC, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 129488 (D. Nev. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judges have broad discretion when ruling on motions in limine under Rule 103(d), but such motions should not be used to resolve factual disputes or weigh evidence. To exclude evidence on a motion in limine, the evidence must be inadmissible on all potential grounds. Unless evidence meets this high standard, evidentiary rulings should be deferred until trial so that questions of foundation, relevancy, and potential prejudice may be resolved in proper context. Although rulings on motions in limine may save time, costs, effort, and preparation, a court is almost always better situated during the actual trial to assess the value and utility of evidence. Allstate Prop. & Cas. Ins. Co. v. Mercury Plastics, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 128738 (D. Nev. 2014); Gonzales v. Shotgun Nev. Invs., LLC, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 129488 (D. Nev. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In limine rulings, as authorized by operation of Rule 103(d), are preliminary and therefore are not binding on the trial judge, who may always change his or her mind during a trial. Denial of a motion in limine does not necessarily mean that all evidence contemplated by the motion will be admitted to trial, but merely means that without the context of trial, the court is unable to determine whether the evidence in question should be excluded. Allstate Prop. & Cas. Ins. Co. v. Mercury Plastics, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 128738 (D. Nev. 2014); Gonzales v. Shotgun Nev. Invs., LLC, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 129488 (D. Nev. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 103(b) focuses on the definitiveness of the district courts ruling because renewed objections to a such definitive decisions are an unnecessary formalism. Rule 103(b) imposes the obligation on counsel to clarify whether an in limine or other evidentiary ruling is definitive when there is doubt on that point. United States v. Young, 753 F.3d 757 (8th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When the district court reserves its ruling or otherwise indicates that a ruling is provisional, the challenger should reintroduce the court to the issue at the appropriate time. United States v. Young, 753 F.3d 757 (8th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 103(b) does not set the bounds of a definitive ruling. However, a pretrial ruling including an express invitation for the party to raise the issue again during trial where its relevance can be better assessed is not definitive within the intendment of Rule 103. United States v. Young, 753 F.3d 757 (8th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Definitive rulings do not invite reconsideration. Therefore, a district courts invitation to re-raise evidentiary challenges renders its ruling non-definitive. The inquiry does not focus on magic words like sustained or overruled when the objection is initially made, but on the overall context of the ruling. When that context includes a district courts invitation to re-raise the issue later at trial, then the ruling is not definitive under Rule 103(b). United States v. Young, 753 F.3d 757 (8th Cir. 2014).
