                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Despite the breadth of Rule 201(f), which clearly states that judicial notice may be taken at any stage of the proceeding, there are circumstances under which it is improper for a district court to take judicial notice after the verdict, such as where unfairness results. Grp. One, Ltd. v. Hallmark Cards, Inc., 407 F.3d 1297 (Fed. Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 201(e) affords a party the opportunity to be heard on timely request. However, a claim that the court erred in taking judicial notice of the laws of physics was rejected where the aggrieved party could have challenged the taking of notice and made a request to be heard on

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 77 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        the issue after the court entered its findings of fact and conclusions of law, but failed to do so. Beasley v. U.S. Welding Serv., Inc., 129 F. Appx 901 (5th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Stock prices listed on the New York Stock Exchange are facts that a court may properly take judicial notice of pursuant to Rule 201. PHP Liquidating, LLC v. Robbins, 128 F. Appx 839 (3d Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        There was no abuse of discretion in refusing to take judicial notice of the authenticity of certain documents and the statements made therein as desired by the plaintiff in a suit under the Civil Liberties Act of 1988, where plaintiff failed to establish that the authenticity and content of the documents was generally known. Murakami v. United States, 398 F.3d 1342 (Fed. Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 201(b)(2) permits a court to take judicial notice of a fact that is capable of accurate and ready determination by resort to sources whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned; therefore, where a defendant challenged his sentencing under the Armed Career Criminals Act, the district court could properly take judicial notice of the fact of defendants 1989 conviction for assault in the first degree in violation of section 120.10 of New Yorks Penal Law for sentencing purposes where the government produced a certificate of disposition showing such conviction in support of the sentence. United States v. Alexander, 123 F. Appx 444 (2d Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Determinations regarding the status of unnamed parties to a litigation are not within the realm of judicially noticeable facts, as such facts are neither generally known within the territorial jurisdiction nor capable of accurate and ready determination by resort to sources whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned. Rodgers v. Horsely, 123 F. Appx 281 (9th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Because the effect of judicial notice is to deprive a party of an opportunity to use rebuttal evidence, cross-examination, and argument to attack contrary evidence, caution must be used in determining that a fact is beyond controversy under Rule 201(b). Rivera v. Philip Morris, Inc., 395 F.3d 1142 (9th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The common knowledge requirement of Rule 201 would be emasculated if a defendant may show merely that the public was aware that a product presented health risks at some vague, unspecified, and undifferentiated level. Therefore, on the evidence presented, it was premature for the district court to take judicial notice of the fact that the link between smoking and specific illnesses allegedly caused by smoking was common knowledge after 1969, some four years after federal law first mandated warning labels on cigarette packages and the same year those warnings were strengthened, which was also the same year in which plaintiffs decedent started smoking. Rivera v. Philip Morris, Inc., 395 F.3d 1142 (9th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A district court did not err in taking judicial notice of statements of fact pursuant to Rule 201 which were derived from a transcript of witness testimony in another case, because the court recognized that the transcripts were sources whose accuracy could not reasonably be questioned. Phonometrics, Inc. v. Hospitality Intl, Inc., 120 F. Appx 341 (Fed. Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial notice would be improper if its effect is to circumvent the general rule that a court reviewing an agency decision may only consider the administrative record that was before the agency. Murakami v. United States, 398 F.3d 1342 (Fed. Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In an ERISA case decided on the administrative record in federal court, judicial notice of various documents including medical dictionaries and scholarly articles was not taken because these materials were not part of the administrative record. Miller v. Hartford Life Ins. Co., 348 F. Supp. 2d 815 (E.D. Mich. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        On a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim predicated on a statute of limitations argument, the trial judge may take judicial notice of certain facts necessary to assessing the statute of limitations argument such as the date of the filing of a previous action, the date of its dismissal, and the grounds for dismissal. Rodi v. S. New England Sch. of Law, 389 F.3d 5 (1st Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court may, under Rule 201, take judicial notice of documents on which allegations in a complaint necessarily rely, even if not expressly referenced in the complaint, provided that the authenticity of those documents is not in dispute. In re Tibco Software, Inc. Sec. Litig., 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 36666 (N.D. Cal. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 78 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Pursuant to Rule 201, documents that are alleged in a complaint and are essential to plaintiffs allegations may be judicially noticed. In re Tibco Software, Inc. Sec. Litig., 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 36666 (N.D. Cal. 2006); In re Applied Signal Tech., Inc. Sec. Litig., 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 24498 (N.D. Cal. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In addition to the complaint, it is proper for the district court to take judicial notice of matters of public record outside the pleadings and consider them for purposes of a motion to dismiss. Jeanne Piaubert, S.A. v. Sefrioui, 2000 U.S. App. LEXIS 2462 (9th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The district court declined to take judicial notice of several newspaper and Internet articles on a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim, though they were cognizable if the case proceeded to summary judgment. In re Cree, Inc. Sec. Litig., 333 F. Supp. 2d 461 (M.D.N.C. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        At the motion-to-dismiss stage of the case, the district judge took judicial notice of a report of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and other publicly filed settlement agreements. In re Natural Gas Commodity Litig., 337 F. Supp. 2d 498 (S.D.N.Y. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The danger of undue prejudice is substantially lower in a bench trial than in a jury trial. The court may therefore take judicial notice of adjudicative facts that might create unfair prejudice in a jury trial and that would be inadmissible as evidence of general character and not strong enough to serve as evidence of habit. Impax Labs., Inc. v. Aventis Pharm., Inc., 333 F. Supp. 2d 265 (D. Del. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial notice is not warranted where the fact is not relevant to any matter before the jury. United States v. Falcon, 957 F. Supp. 1572 (S.D. Fla. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 201(d) does not relieve a party of the duty to gather, organize, and present evidence to the court. Nor does the taking of judicial notice automatically establish the admissibility of evidence. Facts appropriate for judicial notice are self-evident truths that no reasonable person could question, truisms that approach being platitudes or banalities. Wooden v. Mo. Pac. R.R., 862 F.2d 560 (5th Cir. 1989).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial notice cannot be taken of a proposition that is inextricably linked to a host of disputed issues. Hardy v. Johns-Manville Sales Corp., 681 F.2d 334 (5th Cir. 1982).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 79 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Procedure for Notice

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Established Doctrine

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201(d), a court is required to take judicial notice when a party requests it and when that party supplies the court with the necessary information; however, the fact to be noticed must not be subject to reasonable dispute. United States v. Husein, 478 F.3d 318 (6th Cir. 2007); Gulf Ins. Co. v. Glasbrenner, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 32053 (S.D.N.Y. 2006); Senger Bros. Nursery v. E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., 184 F.R.D. 674 (M.D. Fla. 1999); City of Amsterdam v. Daniel Goldreyer, Ltd., 882 F. Supp. 1273 (E.D.N.Y. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court may take judicial notice of a fact pursuant to Rule 201 whether requested or not; however, if a request has been made by a partys motion, that party bears the burden of proving that the matter is not reasonably disputable. Jackson v. Placer Cnty., 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 35436 (E.D. Cal. 2007); Hayes v. Woodford, 444 F. Supp. 2d 1127 (S.D. Cal. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Announcement on the record of the fact that a court is taking judicial notice is necessary. United States v. Lewis, 833 F.2d 1380 (9th Cir. 1987); Colonial Leasing Co. v. Logistics Control Grp. Intl, 762 F.2d 454 (5th Cir. 1985); United States v. Garcia, 672 F.2d 1349 (11th Cir. 1982).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Party is entitled to opportunity to be heard as to propriety of taking judicial notice, and opponent of notice must frequently move for such opportunity. Pickett v. Sheridan Health Care Ctr., 664 F.3d 632 (7th Cir. 2012); Rose v. Hartford Underwriters Ins. Co., 203 F.3d 417 (6th Cir. 2000); Lal v. U.S. Life Ins. Co., 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 88554 (W.D. Mich. 2006); Gibbes v. Rose Hill Plantation Dev. Co., 794 F. Supp. 1327 (D.S.C. 1992); Chen v. Metro. Ins. & Annuity Co., 907 F.2d 566 (5th Cir. 1990); Banks v. Schweiker, 654 F.2d 637 (9th Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Case Applications

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 201(e) does not require that a formal hearing be held before a court may take judicial notice in all circumstances. Jonas v. Gold, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 138472 (D.N.J. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial notice under Rule 201(b) applies to appellate courts taking judicial notice of facts supported by documents not included in the record on appeal, but notice is only appropriate if the factual matter is beyond reasonable controversy. Rule 201(b) proceeds upon the theory that dispensing with traditional methods of proof should only occur in clear cases, and it is not an alternative avenue for amending the complaint after a district court dismisses the suit for failure to state a claim. In re Omnicare, Inc. Sec. Litig., 769 F.3d 455 (6th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 201(e) reflects that caution must be taken to avoid admitting evidence, through the use of judicial notice, in contravention of the relevancy, foundation, and hearsay rules. Out of respect for the adversarial process, a district court should allow the parties to build the factual record themselves as much as possible, and Rule 201(e) explicitly indicates that the parties are entitled to be heard on the propriety of the court noticing facts not tested in the crucible of litigation. Pain Referral Serv., LLC v. Otto, 744 F.3d 1045 (8th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 201(e) indicates that, ordinarily, a party should be given notice that the court intends to judicially notice facts and, when appropriate, should be given an opportunity for discovery germane to a jurisdictional dispute implicated by the noticed facts. Ctr. for Biological Diversity, Inc. v. BP Am. Prod. Co., 704 F.3d 413 (5th Cir. 2013).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The taking of judicial notice by a court before notifying a party is not necessarily improper, as Rule 201(e) specifically contemplates such a possibility, but allows the party an opportunity to be heard if the party so requests. Ctr. for Biological Diversity, Inc. v. BP Am. Prod. Co., 704 F.3d 413 (5th Cir. 2013).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 901(b)(9) is a provision typically employed to authenticate data generated by a mechanism. It provides an illustrative authentication technique, by which the proponent may offer evidence describing a process or system and showing that it produces an accurate result. Such

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 80 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        evidence normally depends for its validity on the premise that the device was in proper working order; however, a court may however take judicial notice of the foundational facts under Rule 201 if the evidence resulted from a process or system that is generally known and accepted as accurate. United States v. Espinal-Almeida, 699 F.3d 588 (1st Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court may properly take judicial notice of factual information appearing on government websites under Rule 201. However, given that the Internet contains an unlimited supply of information with varying degrees of reliability, permanence, and accessibility, it is especially important for parties to have the opportunity to be heard prior to the taking of judicial notice of websites, and Rule 201(e) reflects that policy. Pickett v. Sheridan Health Care Ctr., 664 F.3d 632 (7th Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court may take judicial notice sua sponte pursuant to Rule 201(c). However, where the court does take such judicial notice on its own motion, a party is entitled to be heard on the matter if he so requests. In addition, before a court takes judicial notice, the court should identify the fact it is noticing and its justification for doing so. Osage Tribe of Indians v. United States, 2010 U.S. Claims LEXIS 717 (Fed. Cl. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Pursuant to Rule 201(e), a judge must grant the parties an opportunity to dispute any fact that is judicially noticed. Merzbacher v. Shearin, 732 F. Supp. 2d 527 (D. Md. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial notice precludes either party from introducing evidence to disprove that fact, and where the trial court has taken judicial notice of a fact, Rule 201(g) provides that the jury must be instructed to accept that fact as conclusive. Accordingly, district courts must be cautious in taking judicial notice and do so only when the matter to be noticed is beyond controversy. Hogan v. NW Trust Servs., Inc., 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 45612 (D. Or. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When taking judicial notice of adjudicative facts, the court is required to use the procedures set forth in Rule 201. One of these requirements is proceduralnamely, that the parties be given notice and an opportunity to object to the taking of judicial noticeand a trial court abuses its discretion if it takes judicial notice of such facts without first giving the parties adequate notice and an opportunity to object. Am. Prairie Constr. Co. v. Hoich, 560 F.3d 780 (8th Cir. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        While courts are often required to conduct independent research regarding questions of law, on fact questions, the court should not use the doctrine of judicial notice embodied in Rule 201 to go outside the record unless the facts are matters of common knowledge or are capable of certain verification. Am. Prairie Constr. Co. v. Hoich, 560 F.3d 780 (8th Cir. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The trial court erred in conducting independent research to discover the defendants published book and thereafter take judicial notice of certain statements made in it to support its finding that the defendants CPA was his agent and that the CPA had authority to bind the defendant to a settlement agreement. Am. Prairie Constr. Co. v. Hoich, 560 F.3d 780 (8th Cir. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201(e), prior notification by the court of its intention to take judicial notice is not necessary, and the partys request to be heard may be made after judicial notice has been taken. Lal v. U.S. Life Ins. Co., 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 88554 (W.D. Mich. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        As a general matter, websites and their contents may be proper subjects for judicial notice under Rule 201. However, subsection (d) also contemplates that a party will provide the court with a copy of the document it seeks to have judicially noticed. Thus, where a party fails to provide a printed copy of the website to the court, it is unable to pass on the nature of facts contained within the entire website and cannot determine the accuracy of same, so as to permit judicial notice to be taken under Rule 201. Caldwell v. Caldwell, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 13688 (N.D. Cal. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 201(e) requires the district court to give a party an opportunity to be heard if judicial notice is taken and failure to provide this opportunity combined with the lack of explanation for the notice is more than harmless error. Rose v. Hartford Underwriters Ins. Co., 203 F.3d 417 (6th Cir. 2000); Banks v. Schweiker, 654 F.2d 637 (9th Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A sufficient opportunity to be heard on the propriety of taking judicial notice pursuant to Rule 201(e) was provided by the opportunity to address the matter in her appellate briefs and at oral argument. In re Imdad Khan, 1999 U.S. App. LEXIS 13377 (9th Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 81 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Procedural fairness demands that the party against whom judicial notice would operate be given an opportunity to be heard. Gibbes v. Rose Hill Plantation Dev. Co., 794 F. Supp. 1327 (D.S.C. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Care should be taken by the court to identify the fact it is noticing, and its justification for doing so. Colonial Leasing Co. v. Logistics Control Grp. Intl, 762 F.2d 454 (5th Cir. 1985).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Common sense and experience are not substitutes for the notice procedures. United States v. Bonilla, 648 F.2d 1373 (1st Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Almanac Facts

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Consistent with Rule 201, courts routinely take judicial notice of basic facts, figures, and methods of calculation in sources such as treatises and almanacs. Spears v. United States, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 95138 (W.D. Tex. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The Consumer Price Index as gleaned from the official government website for the Bureau of Labor Statistics belongs to the category of public records of which a court may properly take judicial notice under Rule 201(b). Pickett v. Sheridan Health Care Ctr., 664 F.3d 632 (7th Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Courts commonly use Internet mapping tools, such as Google maps (http://maps. google.com), to take judicial notice of distance and geography pursuant to Rule 201(b). Rindfleisch v. Gentiva Health Sys., Inc., 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 107919 (E.D.N.Y. 2010); Marcavage v. City of New York, 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 107724 (S.D.N.Y. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial notice was properly taken of the 310-yard distance between two locations, as measured using www.gmap-pedometer.com, under Rule 201(b) and (c). Citizens for Peace in Space v. City of Colorado Springs, 477 F.3d 1212 (10th Cir. 2007).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201(b) a court may take judicial notice of the driving distance between two points located in the record using mapping services, such as Mapquest.com (www.mapquest.com), whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned. United States v. Williams, 476 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (M.D. Fla. 2007).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Pursuant to Rule 201, the district court could properly take judicial notice that Hurricane Katrina made landfall on the Gulf Coast and New Orleans on the morning of August 29, 2005. Santa Maria v. Dall. Indep. Sch. Dist., 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 83417 (N.D. Tex. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The actual time of sunset, evening twilight or dusk, and complete darkness were adjudicative facts in a civil case. Fargo v. Phillips, 129 F. Supp. 2d 1075 (E.D. Mich. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The number of rainy days in an area over a two-year period was not a generally known fact, but is capable of accurate and ready determination by resort to sources whose accuracy cannot be questioned. The proponent must supply the court with reliable sources of the information. Weber v. Trinity Meadows Raceway, 1996 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 15302 (N.D. Tex. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Distance between airports was subject to judicial notice. Nw. Airlines, Inc. v. Cnty. of Kent, 955 F.2d 1054 (6th Cir. 1992).
