                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Geographical distances between cities may be noticed. Rainey v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 139 F.R.D. 94 (W.D. La. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Distance comparisons may be noticed. United States v. Garcia, 672 F.2d 1349 (11th Cir. 1982).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Almanac type facts, such as when Fathers Day fell, will be noticed. Allen v. Allen, 518 F. Supp. 1234 (E.D. Pa. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 82 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Court Records

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Established Doctrine

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201, a court may take notice of proceedings in other courts, both within and without the federal judicial system, if those proceedings have a direct relation to matters at issue in the case currently before it. Botelho v. U.S. Bank, N.A., 692 F. Supp. 2d 1174 (N.D. Cal. 2010); Bias v. Moynihan, 508 F.3d 1212 (9th Cir. 2007); Pac. Coast Fedn of Fishermens Assn v. Gutierrez, 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 45852 (E.D. Cal. 2007); Assn of Irritated Residents v. C&R Vanderham Dairy, 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 70890 (E.D. Cal. 2007); Hobby v. State, 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 41047 (W.D. Mich. 2007); Stern v. Farmers Ins. Grp. of Cos., 78 F. Appx 559 (9th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court may take judicial notice of a document filed in another court not for the truth of the matter asserted in the other litigation, but rather to establish the fact of such litigation and related filings. Marsh v. San Diego Cnty., 432 F. Supp. 2d 1035 (S.D. Cal. 2006); Wheeler v. City of Oakland, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 27680 (N.D. Cal. 2006); Taylor v. Charter Med. Corp., 162 F.3d 827 (5th Cir. 1998); City of Amsterdam v. Daniel Goldreyer, Ltd., 882 F. Supp. 1273 (E.D.N.Y. 1995); Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. Rotches Pork Packers, 969 F.2d 1384 (2d Cir. 1992); 797 F. Supp. 1554 (E.D. Cal. 1992); M/Assembly of Cal. v. U.S. Dept of Commerce,V Am. Queen v. San Diego Marine Constr., 708 F.2d 1483 (9th Cir. 1983).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Taking judicial notice of a courts own record is wholly consistent with the provisions of Rule 201. Hobby v. State, 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 41047 (W.D. Mich. 2007); United States v. Pelletier, 469 F.3d 194 (1st Cir. 2006); MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. v. Flintkote Co., 760 F.2d 580 (5th Cir. 1985).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201, judicial records and dockets from the same or a closely related case are proper facts for judicial notice. United States v. Beattie, 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 40115 (N.D. Cal. 2007); Locke v. City of Corpus Christi, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 66777 (S.D. Tex. 2006); Cash Inn, Inc. v. Metro. Dade Cnty., 938 F.2d 1239 (11th Cir. 1991) (meeting minutes introduced at preliminary injunction hearing were noticed); United States v. Wood, 925 F.2d 1580 (7th Cir. 1991) (earlier proceeding noticed); Bolivar v. Pocklington, 137 F.R.D. 202 (D.P.R. 1991) (previous voluntary dismissal); Cagan v. Intervest Midwest Real Estate Corp., 774 F. Supp. 1089 (N.D. Ill. 1991) (prior case); Saucier v. U.S. Fid. & Guar. Co., 765 F. Supp. 334 (S.D. Miss. 1991) (prior conviction); Gen. Am. Life Ins. Co. v. Rana, 769 F. Supp. 1121 (N.D. Cal. 1991) (defendants third-party complaint from separate proceeding); Scott v. Angelone, 771 F. Supp. 1064 (D. Nev. 1991) (courts own opinions, published or not); EEOC v. Tortilleria La Major, 758 F. Supp. 585 (E.D. Cal. 1991) (brief from separate case); Fasi v. Cayetano, 752 F. Supp. 942 (D. Haw. 1990) (notice of appeal in separate case); MacMillan Bloedel Ltd. v. Flintkote Co., 760 F.2d 580 (5th Cir. 1985).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Courts generally do not take judicial notice of findings of fact from other proceedings for their truth because these findings are disputable and usually are disputed. Gas Tech. Inst. v. Rehmat, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 91420 (N.D. Ill. 2006); Hughes v. Freightliner, Inc., 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 44368 (W.D. Va. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        It is generally inappropriate to take judicial notice of factual findings of other courts pursuant to Rule 201. Asset Funding Grp., L.L.C. v. Adams & Reese, L.L.P., 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 106910 (E.D. La. 2009); Miss. State Democratic Party v. Barbour, 491 F. Supp. 2d 641 (N.D. Miss. 2007); Gas Tech. Inst. v. Rehmat, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 91420 (N.D. Ill. 2006); Wyatt v. Terhune, 315 F.3d 1108 (9th Cir. 2003); Weinstein v. Islamic Republic of Iran, 175 F. Supp. 2d 13 (D.D.C. 2001); Taylor v. Charter Med. Corp., 162 F.3d 827 (5th Cir. 1998); Hollo-way v. Lockhart, 813 F.2d 874 (8th Cir. 1987); M/V Am. Queen v. San Diego Marine Constr., 708 F.2d 1483 (9th Cir. 1983).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 83 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Case Applications

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court may properly take judicial notice of its own records, as well as public records, and judicial notice is particularly appropriate for a courts own records in prior litigation related to the case before it. Rocha v. State Dept of Corr. & Rehab., 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 164932 (E.D. Cal. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Although a court may take judicial notice of matters of public record, under Rule 201(b), a court may not take judicial notice of a fact that is subject to reasonable dispute. Thus, a court has authority to take judicial notice that certain proceedings occurred, but a court may not take judicial notice of disputed facts stated in public records. Perdue v. Rodney Corp., 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 102050 (S.D. Cal. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Federal Rule of Evidence 201(b), a district court may take judicial notice of documents filed in other courts not for the truth of the matter asserted in those documents, but rather to establish the fact of such litigation and the existence of related filings. Ray Legal Consulting Grp. v. DiJoseph, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 109935 (S.D.N.Y. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The fact that a judicial action was taken is indisputable and is therefore amenable to judicial notice under Rule 201(b). Accordingly, judicial notice could properly be taken of the district court record in Dukes v. Wal-Mart Stores, one of the most expansive class actions ever certified in the United States. Odle v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 747 F.3d 315 (5th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201(b), judicial notice may properly be taken of the contents of another courts docket. Orabi v. Attorney Gen. of U.S., 738 F.3d 535 (3d Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Court dockets are public records within the scope of Rule 201(b), and judicial notice may properly be taken of dates reflected in a court docket because those dates qualify as adjudicative facts under Rule 201(a). Johnson v. Quaker Oats Co., 2013 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 157 (D.D.C. 2013).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Court orders and filings are the type of documents that are properly noticed under Rule 201(b). In particular, courts may take judicial notice of proceedings of other courts if those proceedings have a direct relation to matters at issue. Nonetheless, the court can only take judicial notice of these documents for the limited purpose of recognizing the judicial act that the order represents on the subject matter of litigation. La. Mun. Police Emps. Ret. Sys. v. Wynn, 2013 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 14013 (D. Nev. 2013).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court ordinarily may treat documents from prior state court adjudications as public records, for purposes of taking judicial notice thereof under Rule 201(b). Davis v. Self, 960 F. Supp. 2d 1276 (N.D. Ala. 2013).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201(b), a court may take judicial notice of a document filed in another court not for the truth of the matter asserted in the other litigation, but rather to establish the fact of such litigation and related filings. Kalimantano GmbH v. Motion in Time, Inc., 939 F. Supp. 2d 392 (S.D.N.Y. 2013).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial records are a source of reasonably indisputable accuracy when they record some judicial action such as dismissing an action, granting a motion, or finding a fact. Thus, courts can properly notice prior judicial acts under Rule 201(b) for the purpose of acting upon them, and judicial records may sometimes be properly noticed to show the acts of the parties or other actors in the litigation; for example, that a complaint was filed, that return of service was made, or that stipulations were entered into. United States v. Ferguson, 681 F.3d 826 (6th Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under state law defining an order of probation to be a tentative and amendable sentence and a final judgment of conviction, such an order qualifies as a judicial record comparable to a plea colloquy or agreement that may also properly be judicially noticed under Rule 201(b). United States v. Ferguson, 681 F.3d 826 (6th Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Pursuant to Rule 201(b), a federal court may properly take judicial notice of a certified transcript of resentencing proceedings occurring in state court, as a source whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned. Johnson v. Uribe, 682 F.3d 1238 (9th Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        By operation of Rule 201(f), the standards of Rule 201(b) for notice a fact that is not subject to reasonable dispute because it can be accurately and readily determined from sources whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned apply to appellate courts taking judicial notice of facts supported by documents not included in the record on appeal, because judicial notice may be

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 84 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        taken at any stage of the proceedings, whether in the trial court or on appeal. United States v. Ferguson, 681 F.3d 826 (6th Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Appellate courts generally will not consider facts outside the record developed before the district court, but under Rule 201(f) may take judicial notice of proceedings in other courts, both within and without the federal judicial system, if those proceedings have a direct relation to matters at issue. United States v. Ferguson, 681 F.3d 826 (6th Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The records of state court proceedings are a source whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned under Rule 201(b), and judicial notice may be taken of such court records. Thus the Internet website for the California Courts, containing the court systems records for filings in the Court of Appeal and the California Supreme Court, is subject to judicial notice. Brooks v. Yates, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 121666 (E.D. Cal. 2011); Coles v. Cate, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 121614 (E.D. Cal. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201(b) a court properly may take judicial notice of pleadings filed in other actions, including a related state court proceeding, because the existence and content of opinions and pleadings are matters capable of accurate and ready determination by resort to official court files that cannot reasonably be questioned. Barnes v. Chase Home Fin., LLC, 825 F. Supp. 2d 1057 (D. Or. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court may take judicial notice of its own records sua sponte under Rule 201(c), and courts may likewise take judicial notice of items or matters in the public record, even when considering a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim under Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6). It is particularly appropriate to do so when the docket of another case before it provides relevant insight pertaining to the grounds for a plaintiffs claims in the instant case. Watkins v. Wells Fargo Bank, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 20295 (S.D. W. Va. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A bankruptcy court may properly take judicial notice of the contents of the docket and pleadings of cases within in its territorial jurisdiction, pursuant to Rule 201(b) and (c). In re Circuit City Stores, Inc., 439 B.R. 652 (E.D. Va. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial notice may be taken of a declaration attached to a notice of default only under the theory that it is a source whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned under Rule 201(b), since it contains information that is not generally known. However, where the person who signed the declaration has not been shown to be a source whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned as required under the rule, the scope of judicial notice that may be taken is limited to the facts of the recording and the date of recording, and the contents of the declaration may not be judicially noticed. Madhvamundi v. WMC Mortg. Corp., 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 122042 (N.D. Cal. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        While a court may take judicial notice of pleadings in other cases pursuant to Rule 201 for the limited purpose of establishing the fact of such litigation or proceeding, the court cannot take judicial notice of the truth of the matters asserted in those other proceedings. Club at Hokulia v. Am. Motorists Ins. Co., 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 114569 (D. Haw. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Facts adjudicated in a prior case fall short of the standard for judicial notice imposed by Rule 201(b), because they are not usually common knowledge, nor derived from an unimpeachable source; taking judicial notice of such facts has the effect of precluding the opposing party from introducing contrary evidence. Indeed, for all practical purposes, judicially noticing such a fact is tantamount to directing a verdict against a party as to the noticed fact. Ricoh Co. Ltd. v. Oki Data Corp., 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 104264 (D. Del. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The record of a state court proceeding is a source whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned for purposes of Rule 201(b), and upon a habeas petitioners request, judicial notice may be taken of court records in the trial and direct appeals of the petitioners underlying criminal case. Torres v. Tilton, 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 95820 (E.D. Cal. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201(b), federal courts may take judicial notice of proceedings in other courts if those proceedings have relevance to the matters at hand. Martin v. Mead Johnson Nutrition Co., 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 105019 (D. Mass. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court may take judicial notice of another courts order under Rule 201(b) for the limited purpose of recognizing the judicial act that the order represents or the subject matter of the litigation: the fact that proceedings occurred in another case and the subject matter thereof. It is improper to take judicial notice of any factual findings, arguments, or legal

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 85 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        conclusions advanced within such order. 126th Ave. Landfill, Inc. v. Pinellas Cnty., 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 91400 (M.D. Fla. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201, courts may only properly judicially notice the fact of certain outcomes in related proceedings; a court cannot accept the individual factual findings of another case as evidence of the truth of the matter. This is so because these factual findings are disputable and usually are disputed. Reneker v. Offill, 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 38526 (N.D. Tex. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201, a court may take judicial notice of matters of public record. Donovan v. Flamingo Palms Villas, LLC, 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 23980 (D. Nev. 2010); Newman v. OneW-est Bank, FSB, 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 29021 (C.D. Cal. 2010); Morfin v. Accredited Home Lenders, Inc., 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 6831 (S.D. Cal. 2010); Conservation Force v. Salazar, 677 F. Supp. 2d 1203 (N.D. Cal. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Court records are a typical subject of judicial notice under Rule 201(b)(2). Along these lines, federal courts may take judicial notice of proceedings in other courts of record and may also take judicial notice of guilty pleas and the factual record associated with those pleas. Great Am. Ins. Co. v. Geostar Corp., 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 20258 (E.D. Mich. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201, a court may take judicial notice of proceedings in other courts, both within and without the federal judicial system, if those proceedings have a direct relation to matters at issue. Adams v. Carey, 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 115472 (E.D. Cal. 2009); Walls v. Quinn, 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 113056 (W.D. Wash. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial notice under Rule 201 is proper only if the record is capable of accurate and ready determination by resort to sources whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned. The accuracy of the record of a federal case may be checked by accessing the PACER system of federal court records; accordingly, such a record cannot reasonably be questioned within the intendment of the rule. Adams v. Carey, 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 115472 (E.D. Cal. 2009); SEC v. Aragon Capital Mgmt. LLC, 672 F. Supp. 2d 421 (S.D.N.Y. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court may properly take judicial notice of an inmates criminal record as maintained by the New York State Department of Correctional Services website, http://nysdocs.lookup.docs.state.ny.us. Ahlers v. Dir., Manhattan Psychiatric Ctr., 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 115420 (S.D.N.Y. 2009); Bloomfield v. Wursenberger, 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 95924 (N.D.N.Y. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Court records, acts, and proceedings in the same or similar federal or state cases are appropriate for judicial notice via Rule 201. Wallace v. Countrywide Home Loans, Inc., 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 110140 (C.D. Cal. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial notice may properly be taken of the record of proceedings in a state case as maintained by the clerks office of the state court where the case is or has been heard. Watson v. State, 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 113438 (M.D. Fla. 2009); Ross v. Arpaio, 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 110322 (D. Ariz. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial notice may properly be taken of a witnesss testimony given in another proceeding, where a transcript of such testimony is available. Under these circumstances, the witnesss testimony is considered to not be subject to reasonable dispute and is further considered to be capable of accurate and ready determination by resort to the transcript, the accuracy of which cannot be questioned. Dietz v. Dietz, 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 103087 (W.D. La. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Court orders and filings are the type of documents that are properly noticed under Rule 201(b). In particular, courts may take judicial notice of proceedings of other courts if those proceedings have a direct relation to matters at issue. Nonetheless, a court can only take judicial notice of such documents for the limited purpose of recognizing the judicial act that the order or filing represents on the subject matter of litigation. Miglin v. Mellon, 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 109235 (D. Nev. 2009); Gallagher v. San Diego Unified Port Dist., 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 78955 (S.D. Cal. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201 a court may take judicial notice of matters of public record, including other complaints filed by the same plaintiff in other federal courts. Webb v. Onizuka, 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 30075 (D. Haw. 2009); Jadwin v. Kern Cnty., 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 28451 (E.D. Cal. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 201 documents previously filed with the court in the same litigation are subject to judicial notice. However, the court may not judicially notice the truth of the

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 86 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        disputed facts contained in such documents. Kesey, LLC v. Francis, 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 28078 (D. Or. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A motion seeking to have the court take judicial notice of the existence and contents of relevant state court records, which attempted to dictate to the court how those records were to be construed for purposes of the current matter, was denied as not being the proper subject of a motion brought pursuant to the judicial notice provisions of Rule 201, inasmuch as the facts set forth in the court records were reasonably susceptible to dispute. Sheridan v. Conway, 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 66913 (D. Idaho 2007).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A sentencing court has the capacity to take judicial notice of its own records under Rule 201. United States v. Pelletier, 469 F.3d 194 (1st Cir. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Federal courts may take judicial notice of proceedings in other courts of record under Rule 201; as such, a federal district court may take judicial notice of the procedural aspects of pleadings filed in a state court that are relevant to the matter before it, including issues such as the statute of limitations. Lohmann v. Allmerica Fin. Life Ins. & Annuity Co., 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 92559 (E.D. Tenn. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court may take judicial notice of documents under Rule 201, but it may not take judicial notice of a fact subject to reasonable dispute; thus, while the court can take notice of the fact that a party filed a claim on a certain day, it cannot take judicial notice of the truth of the facts recited in the pleading embodying its claim. Longorio v. Jacot, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 92125 (E.D. Cal. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Public records and government documents are generally considered not to be subject to reasonable dispute, including public records and government documents available from reliable sources on the Internet. Lal v. U.S. Life Ins. Co., 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 88554 (W.D. Mich. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where the fact at issue is the existence of a statement made by a litigant in a declaration within a bankruptcy proceeding, and not the truth of the statement itself, the accuracy of the fact at issue cannot be reasonably questioned; thus, the district court could, pursuant to Rule 201, take judicial notice of a plaintiffs responses to two schedules filed in her bankruptcy case, which was filed within the district courts territorial jurisdiction. Rose v. Beverly Health & Re-hab. Servs., Inc., 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 91741 (E.D. Cal. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court may refuse to take judicial notice of a decision rendered by an administrative law judge of the Social Security Administration under Rule 201, where the findings and opinion of the administrative law judge are facts that are not undisputed. Hughes v. Freightliner, Inc., 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 44368 (W.D. Va. 2006).
