                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A district court did not commit reversible error when, under Rule 201, it conducted an independent Internet search to confirm its intuition that there are many types of yellow rain hats for sale, a fact that it believed was a matter of common knowledge. As broadband speeds increase and Internet search engines improve, the cost of confirming ones intuitions decreases. Twenty years ago, to confirm an intuition about the variety of rain hats, a trial judge may have needed to travel to a local department store to survey the rain hats on offer. Rather than expend that time, he likely would have relied on his common sense to take judicial notice of the fact that not all rain hats are alike. Today, however, a judge need only take a few moments to

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 91 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        confirm his intuition by conducting a basic Internet search. United States v. Bari, 599 F.3d 176 (2d Cir. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A courts personal knowledge is not sufficient to permit judicial notice (unless the fact is generally known within the territorial jurisdiction of the trial court or capable of accurate and ready determination by resort to sources whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned). Storm Plastics, Inc. v. United States, 770 F.2d 148 (10th Cir. 1985); Pina v. Henderson, 752 F.2d 47 (2d Cir. 1985); United States v. Johnson, 726 F.2d 1018 (4th Cir. 1984).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Ready confirmation does not burden court to check county land records. Country Club Hills Homeowners Assn v. Jefferson Metro. Hous. Auth., 449 N.E.2d 460 (Ohio Ct. App. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Conflicting or Disputed Facts

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Consistent with Rule 201(c), the party requesting judicial notice bears the burden of persuading the court that the requirements of Rule 201(b) are satisfied with respect to the particular fact to be noticedthat is, that it is not reasonably subject to dispute and is capable of immediate and accurate determination by resort to a source whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned. Ismail v. Wells Fargo Bank, N.A., 2013 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 32594 (E.D. Cal. 2013).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        It was not an abuse of discretion to refuse judicial notice of certain statistical evidence purporting to show disparate impact in an employment discrimination case; such information had been previously proffered in another employment discrimination case and both the validity of those statistics, as well as whether they established disparate impact, were at issue in that case. As a result, the statistical evidence was not a matter beyond reasonable controversy within the intendment of Rule 201. Prescott v. Higgins, 538 F.3d 32 (1st Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Since the effect of taking judicial notice under Rule 201 is to preclude a party from introducing contrary evidence and in effect, directing a verdict against him as to the fact noticed, the fact must be one that only an unreasonable person would insist on disputing. Mayes v. City of Hammond, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 50950 (N.D. Ind. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Taking judicial notice, at the appellate level, of the weather on a certain day was acceptable, but taking judicial notice of a newspaper account about the prevalence of automobile air fresheners was improper because such statistical information is not within Rule 201. United States v. Foreman, 369 F.3d 776 (4th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In deciding to dismiss for failure to state a claim, the judicial notice of the stated purpose of a city program as stated on the citys website was not proper since the fact was subject to reasonable dispute. Passa v. City of Columbus, 123 F. Appx 694 (6th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial notice that ninety-mile-per-hour winds sometimes strike the New Jersey shore area was improper. This fact was in dispute between the parties, and different sources gave conflicting evidence of the frequency of such high-velocity winds. Buczek v. Contl Cas. Ins. Co., 378 F.3d 284 (3d Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Because the court may only take judicial notice of undisputed facts, the appellate court could not take judicial notice of the facts alleged in a Securities and Exchange Commission complaint filed in separate proceeding, though the court could take judicial notice of the mere fact that the complaint was filed. Nolte v. Capital One Fin. Corp., 390 F.3d 311 (4th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Factual issues regarding the date when the health risks associated with cigarette smoking became common knowledge precluded the court from taking judicial notice of the public awareness of such risks in a products liability action against three cigarette manufacturers by the family of a smoker who died of lung cancer. Hearn v. R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co., 279 F. Supp. 2d 1096 (D. Ariz. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The simple fact that courts disagree about whether or not to take judicial notice of certain facts suggests that these facts are subject to considerable dispute, such that taking judicial notice of it would be improper. Wright v. Brooke Grp., Ltd., 114 F. Supp. 2d 797 (N.D. Iowa 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 92 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Taking of judicial notice contrary to received testimony of a partys expert was not a violation of the partys due process rights. In re Imdad Khan, 1999 U.S. App. LEXIS 13377 (9th Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Conflicting expert opinion may bar notice. Prestige Homes v. Legouffe, 658 P.2d 850 (Colo. 1983).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Court may not simply select from among conflicting historical materials and adopt one version of facts. Oneida Indian Nation v. New York, 691 F.2d 1070 (2d Cir. 1982).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Alternative factual constructions, if viable, bar judicial notice. Artco Shipping Co. v. Sidermar S.P.A., 417 F. Supp. 207 (S.D.N.Y. 1976).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Limitations on Judicial Notice

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rollover propensities of vehicles and the likely result of over-loading particular vehicles are not matters of common knowledge and, as a result, are not the kind of readily ascertainable facts that satisfy Rule 201(b). United States v. Munoz-Tello, 531 F.3d 1174 (10th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Court may not notice a partys mental state or understanding of some fact. United States v. Southard, 700 F.2d 1 (1st Cir. 1983).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Notice of public attitudes toward drugs denied. Apodaca v. State, 627 P.2d 1023 (Wyo. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Public awareness of injunction due to news coverage would not be noticed. United States v. Baker, 641 F.2d 1311 (9th Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Notice of Law

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Established Doctrine

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Trial judge must regularly take judicial notice of the contents of federal and state laws without any formality of proof or introduction. Chiang v. MBNA, 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 61787 (D. Mass. 2007); Getty Petroleum Mktg., Inc. v. Capital Terminal Co., 391 F.3d 312 (1st Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Foreign law is to be proven as a matter of fact. Weiss v. Glemp, 792 F. Supp. 215 (S.D.N.Y. 1992); Technical Servs., Inc. v. Rockwell Intl Corp., 927 F.2d 1198 (11th Cir. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Case Applications

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In considering the interpretation of the Guarantee Clause of the U.S. Constitution, as set out in Article IV, Section 4, and whether the enactment of the Taxpayers Bill of Rights in Colorado violates the Guarantee Clause, is in direct conflict with provisions of the Colorado Enabling Act, 18 Stat. 474 (1875), and impermissibly amends the Colorado Constitution, a court has the authority to take judicial notice of other state constitutional provisions regulating the power of the legislative branch to tax and spend. Kerr v. Hickenlooper, 744 F.3d 1156 (10th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Recent decisions of the U.S. Supreme Court are not appropriate subjects for judicial notice because, as stated in Rule 201(a), the provisions of Rule 201 as a whole govern only judicial notice of adjudicative facts. Kruska v. Perverted Justice Found., Inc., 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 45072 (D. Ariz. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        It is questionable whether a court may, pursuant to Rule 201(a) and (b), take judicial notice of the proposition, supported by certain case law, that it is generally accepted that a sale of an estates undivided interest in property held in common with others will generate substantially less than a sale of the entire property free of co-owners interests. In re Spickelmire, 433 B.R. 792 (Bankr. D. Idaho 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 201 was not intended to apply to questions that are characterized as matters of law rather than matters of fact. The manner in which law is fed into the judicial process is

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 93 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        never a proper concern of the rules of evidence but, rather, is within the purview of the rules of procedure. United States v. Knauer, 707 F. Supp. 2d 379 (E.D.N.Y. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 201(b)(2) authorizes a court to consider the federal regulations governing handicapped access to buildings as adjudicative facts. McTernan v. City of York, 577 F.3d 521 (3d Cir. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Although it is unnecessary to take judicial notice of an opinion published by the California Court of Appeal, judicial notice may nevertheless be taken of such opinion under Rule 201, which allows a district court to take judicial notice of orders or decisions or proceedings of any federal or state court. Allen v. Sisto, 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 93728 (E.D. Cal. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        City charters and ordinances are proper subjects for judicial notice under Rule 201, as they are considered within the publics common knowledge. Gallagher v. San Diego Unified Port Dist., 2009 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 78955 (S.D. Cal. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial notice of law is the name given to the common sense doctrine that the FRE governing admissibility and proof of documents generally do not make sense to apply to statutes or judicial opinions (which are technically documents) because they are presented to the court as law, not to the jury as evidence. In the federal system, the law of any state of the union, whether depending upon statutes or upon judicial opinions, is a matter of which the courts of the United States are bound to take judicial notice, without plea or proof. Chiang v. MBNA, 2007 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 61787 (D. Mass. 2007).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A Municipal Code section falls within the ambit of Rule 201(b)(2) as it is capable of accurate and ready determination by resort to sources whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned. Wheeler v. City of Oakland, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 27680 (N.D. Cal. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A district court may take judicial notice of federal regulations pursuant to Rule 201, and such act may be made mandatory by the plain language of 44 U.S.C. 1507. Thuringer v. Am. Natl Red Cross, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 8972 (N.D. Iowa 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court may take judicial notice of regulations issued by federal agencies. In re Applied Signal Tech., Inc. Sec. Litig., 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 24498 (N.D. Cal. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Although a court reviewing an agency decision is usually limited to the record that was before the agency, in an immigration case the appellate court could properly take judicial notice of the fact that the Research and Analysis Wing was an agency of the Indian government similar in purpose to the CIA or KGB. Singh v. Ashcroft, 393 F.3d 903 (9th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Although the trial judge must regularly take judicial notice of the contents of federal and state laws without any formality of proof or introduction, municipal ordinances must be put into evidence and proven as a matter of fact. Getty Petroleum Mktg., Inc. v. Capital Terminal Co., 391 F.3d 312 (1st Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where a state statute incorporated by reference a private building code, the party invoking the statute had to offer and prove the code as a piece of ordinary evidence. Getty Petroleum Mktg., Inc. v. Capital Terminal Co., 391 F.3d 312 (1st Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Judicial notice of several municipal ordinances related to rent control was permissible. Ventura Mobilehome Communities Owners Assn v. City of San Buenaventura, 371 F.3d 1046 (9th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court took judicial notice of a directive issued by the state Commissioner of Conservation. Eagle Lake Estates, L.L.C., et al. v. Cabot Oil & Gas Corp., 330 F. Supp. 2d 778 (E.D. La. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where there is no dispute as to the authenticity of transcripts of a legislative debate, the court could take judicial notice of such legislative history in determining a motion for summary judgment challenging the constitutionality of a statute. Levy v. Scranton, 780 F. Supp. 897 (N.D.N.Y. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Opinion of state attorney general noticed. KVUE, Inc. v. Austin Broad. Corp., 709 F.2d 922 (5th Cir. 1983).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        State law must be noticed. United States v. Atwell, 71 F.R.D. 357 (D. Del. 1976).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 94 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Adjudicative Versus Legislative Facts

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Established Doctrine

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Adjudicative facts are matters that normally go to the jury, relating to the parties, their activities, their properties, their businesses, concerning who did what, where, when, how and with what motive or intent. They are the facts of the particular case. United States v. Kraft, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 26377 (D.N.D. 2006); Qualley v. Clo-Tex Intl, Inc., 212 F.3d 1123 (8th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Legislative facts do not relate specifically to the activities or characteristics of the litigants. Rather, such facts have relevance to legal reasoning and the law-making process, whether in the formulation of a legal principle or ruling by a judge or court or in the enactment of a legislative body. A court generally relies upon legislative facts when it purports to develop a particular law or policy and thus considers material wholly unrelated to the activities of the parties. United States v. Kraft, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 26377 (D.N.D. 2006); Qualley v. Clo-Tex Intl, Inc., 212 F.3d 1123 (8th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Mandatory judicial notice requirement of Rule 201(d) governs only judicial notice of adjudicative facts; it does not deal with judicial notice of legislative facts. United States v. Wolny, 133 F.3d 758 (10th Cir. 1998).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Case Applications

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A legislative fact, for purposes of judicial notice under Rule 201(a), is one that does not involve the facts of a particular case, but rather is a fact that has relevance to legal reasoning, such as the proposed interpretation of a regulation. Owino v. Holder, 771 F.3d 527 (9th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In an immigration case, official U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services and INS documents, including a memorandum, fact sheet, and a letter from the Director of the Asylum Division, USCIS, to all Asylum Office directors and deputy directors, each of which sets out those agencies interpretations of 8 C.F.R. 208.6, were all deemed to be legislative facts. Accordingly, they could all properly be considered without regard to the requirements of Rule 201. Owino v. Holder, 771 F.3d 527 (9th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Adjudicative facts, for purposes of judicial notice under Rule 201, are simply the facts of the particular case that must not be subject to reasonable dispute and that are capable of accurate and ready determination by resort to sources whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned. While a court has wide discretion to take judicial notice of adjudicative facts under Rule 201, such discretion must be exercised with caution. Al-Rayes v. Willingham, 2014 Bankr. LEXIS 3180 (Bankr. M.D. Fla. 2014); Ardalan v. McHugh, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 106984 (N.D. Cal. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Adjudicative facts within the intendment of Rule 201(a) are facts that relate to the parties, addressing who did what, where, when, how, and with what motive or intent. Judicial notice of such facts is governed by Rule 201(b). In re Grasso, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 94274 (E.D. Pa. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Legislative facts, for purposes of Rule 201(a), are facts that help a tribunal or court to determine the content of law and policy and to exercise its judgment or discretion in determining what course of action to take. They have relevance to legal reasoning and the lawmaking process, whether in the formation of a legal principle or ruling by a judge or court or in the enactment of a legislative body. They are ordinarily general and do not concern the immediate parties. Legislative history, and social science studies, can be considered as legislative facts that are outside the scope of Rule 201, the requirements of which only apply to adjudicative facts by operation of Rule 201(a). Silvester v. Harris, 2014 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 118284 (E.D. Cal. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court has wide discretion to take judicial notice of appropriate adjudicative facts at any stage in a proceeding, including at the summary judgment stage, pursuant to Rule 201(d). Lodge v. Kondaur Capital Corp., 750 F.3d 1263 (11th Cir. 2014).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 201(a) does not bar a court from taking notice of a legislative fact, which is a matter left unregulated by Rule 201. Federal courts have taken judicial notice of legislative facts when

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 95 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        construing or applying the U.S. Constitution or statutes, including determining the validity of administrative regulations. Hightower v. City & Cnty. of San Francisco, 2013 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 12039 (N.D. Cal. 2013).
