                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        factor, including the reasonableness of or an excuse for the delay, lack of prejudice, or egregious misconduct by the accused infringer. Crown Packaging Tech., Inc. v. Rexam Beverage Can Co., 679 F. Supp. 2d 512 (D. Del. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Any presumption under the District of Columbias Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act that a driver operates a car with the owners consent was not itself a piece of evidence and could not be treated or given weight as evidence under Rule 301. Athridge v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co., 585 F. Supp. 2d 20 (D.D.C. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The burden of production resting upon the Commissioner in a Social Security disability benefits case in which a plaintiff is entitled to the presumption of disability based upon the principles set forth in the remedial order described in Dixon v. Shalala, 54 F.3d 1019 (2d Cir. 1995), is to produce substantial evidence of non-disability during the relevant time perioda heavier burden than that required by Rule 301. Fagan v. Astrue, 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 67611 (S.D.N.Y. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When a defendant challenges a plaintiffs claimed new domicile, there is a presumption in favor of plaintiffs previously established domicile. A plaintiff can meet her burden of production and rebut the presumption by demonstrating that she has registered to vote, applied for a new drivers license and surrendered her old license, leased property, opened a bank account, paid utilities, and paid state income taxes in her new domicile. Doe v. Schwerzler, 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 31671 (D.N.J. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When a defendant fails to appear in an immigration proceeding, the Ninth, Third, and Eighth Circuits have approved the following approach: where a petitioner had appeared at earlier immigration proceedings, had no motive to avoid the immigration proceedings, and in fact had initiated proceedings to obtain an immigration benefit, a statement or affidavit by the petitioner stating that he or she had not received notice should ordinarily suffice to overcome the presumption of receipt. Silva-Carvalho Lopes v. Mukasey, 517 F.3d 156 (2d Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a Title VII employment discrimination case, although the McDonnell Douglas framework places the burden on the defendant of producing an explanation to rebut the plaintiffs prima facie case, consistent with Rule 301, the ultimate burden of persuading the trier of fact that the defendant intentionally discriminated on the basis of an impermissible factor remains at all times with the plaintiff. If the employer succeeds in articulating such a reason, the presumption of discrimination arising from the establishment of the prima facie case drops from the picture and the burden shifts back to the plaintiff to show both that the employers proffered reason was merely a pretext for impermissible discrimination and that the plaintiffs race, national origin, and/or gender was the actual motivating factor. Ofoedu v. St. Francis Hosp. & Med. Ctr., 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 68704 (D. Conn. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A party need only establish basic facts in order to invoke the presumption of investor reliance on a public statement; the nonmoving party has the burden of establishing the nonexistence of the presumed fact once the party invoking the presumption establishes the basic facts giving rise to it. Bowe v. PolyMedica Corp., 432 F.3d 1 (1st Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a fraud-on-the-market securities action, whether a market was efficient bears on the presumption of investor reliance. The question of how much evidence of efficiency is necessary for a court to accept the fraud-on-the-market presumption of reliance at the class-certification stage is one of degree. District courts must draw these lines sensibly, mindful that evidence of fundamental value may be relevant to the determination of informational efficiency. Bowe v. PolyMedica Corp., 432 F.3d 1 (1st Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The fraud-on-the-market presumption in securities cases establishes only a presumption of reliance by investors, a presumption that can be rebutted at trial. Bowe v. PolyMedica Corp., 432 F.3d 1 (1st Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        As is often the case in patent law, the presumption of enablement in a prior art patent is not a true presumption under Rule 301 but merely a shifting of the burden of proving nonenablement on the patentee. Amgen, Inc. v. Hoechst Marion Roussel, Inc., 339 F. Supp. 2d 202 (D. Mass. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under the Truth in Lending Act, a mortgagee had to provide mortgagors with two copies of the notice of the mortgagors right to rescind. The plaintiff-mortgagee could not overcome the presumption of receipt of the notice, created by their signing a form to that effect, by

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 124 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        arguing that all of the documents they received were in a single envelope that did not contain the notices. Jackson v. New Century Mortg. Corp., 320 F. Supp. 2d 608 (E.D. Mich. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a bankruptcy case, service of a summons on a creditor through the mail was sufficient to establish personal jurisdiction even though the creditor argued that he had trouble receiving mail at his address. In re Peralta, 317 B.R. 381 (B.A.P. 9th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Regarding a debtors allegedly fraudulent transfer of property, if there are seven or more badges of fraud, as defined in the Uniform Fraudulent Transfers Act, a presumption of fraud arises. In re Zeigler, 2005 Bankr. LEXIS 142 (Bankr. N.D. Ill. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a bankruptcy proceeding, the presumption of insolvency satisfied the plaintiffs burden when defendant produced insufficient evidence to overcome the presumption. The court did not need to address defendants motion to exclude testimony of plaintiffs own expert witnesses. In re Wallace Bookstores, 2004 Bankr. LEXIS 408 (E.D. Ky. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Use of the word presumption in business judgment rule decisions does not create a presumption in the procedural sense of imposing a burden of going forward with evidence. Rather, the courts are merely expressing the substantive rule of director liability. Bal Harbor Club, Inc. v. AVA Dev., Inc., 316 F.3d 1192 (11th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In an action on an accidental death policy, the presumption against suicide can never shift the burden of proof away from the insured. Thus, while the presumption may control in the complete absence of evidence, it cannot be used as a tie-breaker when actual evidence conflicts. Eliskalns v. Provident Life & Accident Ins. Co., 2000 U.S. App. LEXIS 21970 (9th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where plaintiff hired an expert previously consulted by defendant, it is doubtful that Rule 301 applies to the potential revelation to plaintiff of defendants work product. Any presumption of disclosure that may apply is not irrebuttable and would not shift the burden of proof that defendant must bear in showing probability of prejudice, of litigation unfairness, or taint. A possible speculative impropriety is insufficient to disqualify plaintiffs counsel. P&G v. Haugen, 183 F.R.D. 571 (D. Utah 1998).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The common law of fraudulent conveyances shifts the burden of both production and persuasion to the defendants once multiple badges of fraud have been established; Rule 301 should not be applied to change this allocation of burdens. Kelly v. Armstrong, 141 F.3d 799 (8th Cir. 1998).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Whether the particular person who spoils evidence has notice of the relationship between that evidence and the underlying claim is relevant to the fact-finders inquiry as to whether documents unavailability warrants negative inference, but it does not necessarily dictate the resolution of that inquiry; critical part of the foundation that must be laid depends, rather, on institutional notice, the aggregate knowledge possessed by a party and its agents, servants, and employees. Testa v. Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., 144 F.3d 173 (1st Cir. 1998).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A debtor must offer substantial and believable evidence contrary to the presumed intent of 11 U.S.C. 23(a)(2)(C) in order to demonstrate nonfraudulent intent. In re Ellingsworth, 212 Bankr. 326 (Bankr. W.D. Mo. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The presumption that a government official acted in good faith is irrelevant where the court has not yet reached the merits of the case and only is deciding whether discovery is warranted. NEC Corp. v. U.S. Dept of Commerce, 958 F. Supp. 624 (Ct. Intl Trade 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        After plaintiff presents a prima facie case of discrimination under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, defendant may rebut plaintiffs slight presumption by articulation of a legitimate, nondiscriminatory reason for the action at issue and cause the presumption to drop from the case. Stone v. Ga. Power Co., 902 F. Supp. 1578 (M.D. Ga. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        To rebut a presumption of taint in a motion to disqualify opposing counsel, a party may present admissible, probative, and material evidence that, if believed, would support a finding that the challenged attorney had not in fact been tainted by contact with movants counsel rather than disprove the predicate facts. Baker v. Bridgestone/Firestone, Inc., 893 F. Supp. 1349 (N.D. Ohio 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Once a patentee clearly establishes or makes a strong showing of likelihood of success on the merits, including ongoing infringement, the party receives a presumption of irreparable harm that will suffice to permit the court to find irreparable harm absent evidence from

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 125 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        the record to outweigh the finding. CVI/BETA Ventures, Inc. v. Custom Optical Frames, Inc., 893 F. Supp. 508 (D. Md. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence required to rebut a presumption of insolvency must reach a level in which it reasonably supports a finding to the contrary. Johnson v. Winston, Reuber & Byrne, P.C., 189 Bankr. 744 (N.D. Iowa 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Longstanding presumption in admiralty law under the Supreme Courts decision in The Louisiana, 70 U.S. 164 (U.S. 1865), is part of governing substantive maritime law, and its shift of the burden of persuasion overrides the more limited effect of presumptions under Rule 301 where vessels become unmoored. Hood v. Knappton Corp., 986 F.2d 329 (9th Cir. 1993).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A known creditors denial of receipt was insufficient to rebut presumption that proper notice of the bar date for filing proofs of claims in the bankruptcy case was given; therefore, creditors were not entitled to late proofs of claim. In re Schepps Food Stores, Inc., 152 B.R. 136 (Bankr. S.D. Tex. 1993).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The district court held that a presumption of administrative regularity existed in favor of the United States, with respect to the acts of its officials. Bassett v. United States, 782 F. Supp. 113 (M.D. Ga. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Knowledge of the law may be presumed for persons with continuous representation by counsel. Lovell v. United States, 794 F. Supp. 584 (W.D. Va. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where employer failed to keep personnel records required by Title VII, employee was entitled to rely on inference that records would have supported her case. Stender v. Lucky Stores, Inc., 803 F. Supp. 259 (N.D. Cal. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In prison civil rights case, irreparable harm would be presumed upon a showing that the Constitution has been violated. Kaiser v. Sacramento, 780 F. Supp. 1309 (E.D. Cal. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        State law presumption against suicide was overcome by statements in police report, coroners report, and death certificate, shifting burden to opposition to come forward with support for a reasonable conflicting inference against suicide. Duncan v. Am. Home Assurance Co., 747 F. Supp. 1418 (M.D. Ala. 1990).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Good faith of government officials and counsel is for some purposes presumed. In re Thirty-Nine Admin. Subpoenas, 754 F. Supp. 5 (D. Mass. 1990).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Adoption of the federal rules did not modify the substantive burdens and presumptions long established in federal admiralty law. Am. Petrofina v. M/V Shoko Maru, 837 F.2d 1324 (5th Cir. 1988); Self v. Great Lakes Dredge & Dock Co., 832 F.2d 1540 (11th Cir. 1987); James v. River Parishes Co., 686 F.2d 1129 (5th Cir. 1982).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a disability termination proceeding, there is a presumption that a claimant who has previously been determined to be disabled remains disabled. Rush v. Secy of Health & Human Servs., 738 F.2d 909 (8th Cir. 1984).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Res ipsa loquitur may be treated as Rule 301 presumption. Wilson v. United States, 645 F.2d 728 (9th Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 126 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 302 Applying State Law to Presumptions in Civil Cases

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Established Doctrine

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Congress did not give federal courts unbridled discretion to preempt state substantive law on all arguably procedural matters, as evidenced by Rule 302, which expressly provides for the application of state law regarding presumptions. Sims v. Great Am. Life Ins. Co., 469 F.3d 870 (10th Cir. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In civil actions and proceedings, under Rule 302 the effect of a presumption respecting a fact that is an element of a claim or defense as to which state law supplies the rule of decision is determined in accordance with state law. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co. v. Hawkins, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 13511 (E.D. Mich. 2011); Hernandez v. Madrigal, 2010 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 46364 (E.D. Cal. 2010); Daniel v. Ben E. Keith Co., 97 F.3d 1329 (10th Cir. 1996); Welsh v. United States, 844 F.2d 1239 (6th Cir. 1988) (medical malpractice diversity cases).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where there is conflicting state precedent at the intermediate state appellate court level and no clear direction for the states supreme court, the federal court may look to the laws of other states for guidance, in addition to other related precedents from the particular state, when trying to discern whether a presumption would exist in the particular state. Maynard v. Ind. Harbor Belt R.R. Co., 997 F. Supp. 1128 (N.D. Ind. 1998).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Case Applications

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Application of the state law is called for only when the presumption operates upon a substantive element of the claim or defense. Accordingly, Rule 302 does not require state law to be applied when the presumption operates upon a lesser aspect of the case, that is, tactical or procedural presumptions. Examples of such tactical and procedural presumptions include the presumption establishing the receipt of a mailed letter, which operates tactically as a rule of convenience. Kokins v. Teleflex, Inc., 621 F.3d 1290 (10th Cir. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a products liability case, a Colorado state statute creating a presumption that a product is not defective once it has been on the market for ten years operates with regard to the key substantive issue of defect vel non. Accordingly, it operates with respect to an element of a claim or defense as to which state law supplies the rule of decision within the intendment of Rule 302, and the effect of that presumption must be determined in accordance with Colorado law. Kokins v. Teleflex, Inc., 621 F.3d 1290 (10th Cir. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Assuming that it applies under Rule 302, any presumption under the District of Columbias Motor Vehicle Safety Responsibility Act that a driver operates a car with the owners consent is not itself a piece of evidence and cannot be treated or given weight as evidence under Rule 301. Athridge v. Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co., 585 F. Supp. 2d 20 (D.D.C. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 302, the effect of a presumption in a federal civil case is to be determined in accordance with state law. Thus, it was proper, based on Kentucky law, to give a jury instruction concerning the permissible inferences that could be drawn in a sexual harassment case from the loss or destruction of evidence possessed by the employer. West v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 98246 (W.D. Ky. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 302, the effect of a presumption in a federal civil case is to be determined in accordance with state law. Thus, where plaintiff established that she was entitled to a presumption under Rule 301 that her employer had destroyed notes of her exit interview, it was proper, based on Kentucky law, to give a jury instruction concerning the permissible inferences that could be drawn in a sexual harassment case from the loss or destruction of evidence possessed by the employer. West v. Tyson Foods, Inc., 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 98246 (W.D. Ky. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Presumptions created by a states rules of evidence do not apply in federal court, where the FRE are employed. Troutman v. Official Comm. of Unsecured Creditors of Troutman Inv. Co. (In re Troutman Inv. Co.), 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 18047 (D. Or. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 127 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 302, state law supplies any inference or presumption arising from the spoliation of evidence. However, one needs to resort to state law for guidance as to sanctions for spoliation of evidence under Rule 302 only if the complained-of conduct could create such an inference or presumption. Louisville Gas & Elec. Co. v. Contl Field Sys., Inc., 420 F. Supp. 2d 764 (W.D. Ky. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where District of Columbia law created a presumption that a person operating a vehicle is doing so with the owners consent and conflicting evidence on the issue of consent is before the fact-finder, the judge must instruct the jury to find that consent was present unless the defendants establish by a preponderance that consent did not exist. This was a departure from the bubble-bursting theory of presumptions, but the departure was justified when the presumption is founded on a strong social policy. Athridge v. Iglesias, 2005 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 319 (D.D.C. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A presumption in Pennsylvania law that debts older than twenty years have been paid still operates with full force in federal cases including the position, under Pennsylvania law, that the presumption also shifts the burden of persuasion. Griffith v. Mellon Bank, N.A., 328 F. Supp. 2d 536 (E.D. Pa. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Rule 302, in a diversity case, the effect of the presumption under state law that debts more than twenty years old have been paid is governed by state law. Under state law the plaintiff, who sought payment on an old certificate of deposit, bore the burden of overcoming the presumption. Griffith v. Mellon Bank, N.A., 328 F. Supp. 2d 536 (E.D. Pa. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Court may presume that debtor established Keogh and IRA accounts in good faith where debtors claim to the accounts against attachment turns on the good faith of the debtor, presumption of state law is that people act in good faith, and neither party submitted evidence on the issue. In re Ritter, 190 B.R. 323 (Bankr. N.D. Ill. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 128 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ARTICLE IV:RELEVANCE AND ITS LIMITS

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 401Test for Relevant Evidence

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        General Principles

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Established Doctrine

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        All relevant evidence is generally admissible at trial.Dortch v. Fowler, 2009 U.S. App. LEXIS 26009 (6th Cir. 2009); United States v. Cresta, 825 F.2d 538 (1st Cir. 1987); Bettius & Sanderson, P.C. v. Natl Union Fire Ins. Co., 839 F.2d 1009 (4th Cir. 1988).
