                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        What counts as the Rule 403 probative value of an item of evidence, as distinct from its Rule 401 relevance, may be calculated by comparing evidentiary alternatives. Old Chief v. United States, 519 U.S. 172 (U.S. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rulings on admissibility where a concession is proffered should be made not on the basis of Rule 401 relevance but on such considerations as waste of time and undue prejudice. Old Chief v. United States, 519 U.S. 172 (U.S. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 171 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Even without the governments acceptance, defendants offer to admit that the prior conviction element was satisfied was good evidence. Old Chief v. United States, 519 U.S. 172 (U.S. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Although an out-of-court statement qualifies under an exception to the hearsay rule, the court may nevertheless exclude it if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice. United States v. Desanges, 921 F. Supp. 349 (W.D. Va. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        That the evidence depicts outrageous conduct does not make it prejudicial. Foley v. City of Lowell, 948 F.2d 10 (1st Cir. 1991); Rollins v. Bd. of Governors for Higher Educ., 761 F. Supp. 939 (D.R.I. 1991) (testimony simply adverse is not unfairly prejudicial).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 403 may bar evidence of other sexual conduct of a complaining witness where Rule 412 is not strictly applicable. United States v. Payne, 944 F.2d 1458 (9th Cir. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Probative value must be weighed in light of the proponents theory of disputed facts, not the opponents. Johnson v. Wash. Metro. Area Transit Auth., 764 F. Supp. 1568 (D.D.C. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The standard for exclusion of evidence under Rule 403 is exacting, but significant delay, confusion, or prejudice will support rejection of proof. C.A. Assocs. v. Dow Chem., 918 F.2d 1485 (10th Cir. 1990).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Limited relevance of item means small amount of prejudice may outweigh. United States v. Davis, 838 F.2d 909 (7th Cir. 1988) ($120,000 in cash received in drug case; harmless).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Irrelevant evidence need not be admitted regardless of the balance of prejudice.Garraghty v. Jordan, 830 F.2d 1295 (4th Cir. 1987).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 403 may require exclusion of habit evidence meeting Rule 406 requirements. Maynard v. Sayles, 817 F.2d 50 (8th Cir. 1987).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Lay opinion is tested by Rule 403 balance even where otherwise appropriate. Hogan v. AT&T, 812 F.2d 409 (8th Cir. 1987).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence admissible under Rule 408 may nonetheless raise prejudice concerns under 403. Weir v. Fed. Ins. Co., 811 F.2d 1387 (10th Cir. 1987).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Simple relevance objection under Rule 401 may not preserve claim that exclusion was required under 403 balancing. Cook v. Spencer, 688 F.2d 1017 (5th Cir. 1982).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that wastes time may be excluded, whether the waste is in the offer or probable rebuttal. United States v. Bouye, 688 F.2d 471 (7th Cir. 1982).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Collateral impeachment may be barred under the rule. United States v. Matlock, 675 F.2d 981 (8th Cir. 1982).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prosecution may assert prejudice and invoke Rule 403. United States v. Milstead, 671 F.2d 950 (5th Cir. 1982) (barring irrelevant proposed impeachment).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Surprise is not generally a basis for Rule 403 exclusion; a continuance is the remedy. F.&S. Offshore, Inc. v. K.O. Steel Castings, Inc., 662 F.2d 1104 (5th Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Proffered stipulation may be considered in Rule 403 balance, though colorless admission need not generally be accepted. Cleveland v. Cleveland Elec., 538 F. Supp. 1257 (N.D. Ohio 1980).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Objection is required to trigger balancing under rule. United States v. Long, 574 F.2d 761 (3d Cir. 1978).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Confusing evidence should be barred. Rozier v. Ford Motor Co., 573 F.2d 1332 (5th Cir. 1978).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Stale evidence may be barred. United States v. Nu-Phonics, Inc., 433 F. Supp. 1006 (E.D. Mich. 1977).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Trial Management Matters

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Limits on length of proceedings are permitted under Rule 403 so long as the court monitors fairness as proceedings unfold. MCI v. AT&T, 708 F.2d 1081 (7th Cir. 1983); SCM Corp. v. Xerox Corp., 77 F.R.D. 10 (D. Conn. 1977).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Limits on number of witnesses on specific facts are discretionary under Rule 403. Donovan v. Burger King Corp., 672 F.2d 221 (1st Cir. 1982); United States v. IBM Corp., 87 F.R.D. 411 (S.D.N.Y. 1980).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 172 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 403 does not warrant imposition of rigid time limits on testimony. Johnson v. Ashby, 808 F.2d 676 (8th Cir. 1987); MCI Commcns v. AT&T, 708 F.2d 1081 (7th Cir. 1983); Flaminio v. Honda Motor Co., 733 F.2d 463 (7th Cir. 1984).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Drug and Alcohol Proof

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Courts have admitted evidence of drug possession over Rule 403 objections when the drug possession tends to corroborate an element of a separate criminal offense. Common v. City of Chicago, 661 F.3d 940 (7th Cir. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A district court did not abuse its discretion in excluding, under Rule 403, evidence concerning an alleged drug smugglers acts in connection with a drug trafficking incident other than the one under consideration. Disputes relating to a completely different scenario involving another drug-trafficking episodeand the evidentiary disputes accompanying itwould assuredly have diverted the attention of the jury, confused the issues actually to be decided, and unfairly prejudiced the conduct of the trial within the intendment of the rule. United States v. Ramos, 537 F.3d 439 (5th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A court improperly excluded expert evidence that a plaintiffs marijuana use could have contributed to her injuries when the experts testimony was based only on the plaintiffs emergency room statement that she had smoked weed and not on any physical examination of the plaintiff. Foradori v. Harris, 523 F.3d 477 (5th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a trial for possession of cocaine with intent to distribute, a defendant was not unfairly prejudiced by evidence that he hid the cocaine in his daughters homework, since he disputed that the drugs were his and the evidence was probative on that fact. United States v. Garner, 281 F. Appx 571 (7th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Admission of orders authorizing wiretaps in a criminal prosecution of six defendants for conspiring to distribute methamphetamine in violation of federal law was problematic under Rule 403, where although the government claimed that the orders were presented to assure the jury that the wiretaps were legal and to allay any fears about illegal surveillance, the risk of prejudice in revealing the basis for the issuance of the ordersthat the defendants have committed, are committing, and will continue to commit violations of offenses involving the receiving, concealment, buying, selling or otherwise dealing in narcotic or other dangerous drugsto the jury was deemed real and other, less prejudicial ways existed to establish the legality of the wiretaps without revealing the exact findings on which the orders authorizing them were based. United States v. Gray, 410 F.3d 338 (7th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rehabilitation evidence that a government informant had cooperated in cases against approximately twenty other individuals, resulting in guilty pleas in three of the six cases that had been resolved, was relevant, and its probative value was not outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, in a prosecution for distribution of cocaine base. Although defendants case was the first one in which the informant cooperated, by the time the informant conducted controlled drug transaction with defendant, he had given the other names to the government and eventually assisted in investigations of those persons. Without the evidence of other cooperation, the jury could have incorrectly believed that informants plea deal rested solely on defendants case, making a motive to frame defendant more reasonable. Court instructed the jury that it could not infer defendants guilt from the evidence of guilty pleas in other cases in which the informant cooperated. United States v. Henderson, 337 F.3d 914 (7th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testimony admitting drug value and veiled drug structure testimony is admissible because it did not implicate the defendant in any way as a member of the organization, nor did it take that general information testified to and apply it to the defendants conduct. United States v. Galindo-Armendariz, 73 F. Appx 245 (9th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Blood alcohol test results taken two hours after an accident were admissible under Rule 403 against the driver of a car that killed two people because they were relevant to establish that she committed the crime of driving under the influence of alcohol when the deaths occurred; this probative value was too high to permit exclusion. United States v. First Smoke, 35 F. Appx 337 (9th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prior conviction for drug possession of store clerk who saw defendant trying on a dark baseball cap of the same type worn by bank thief in offense charged was properly excluded, since it

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 173 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        had little or no bearing on the reliability of her testimony. United States v. Galati, 230 F.3d 254 (7th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Of the plaintiffs four hospitalizations for alcohol abuse, only the one at the time of the events at issue overcomes Rule 403 as evidence that his decision-making abilities at the time were impaired. Conway v. Icahn & Co., 16 F.3d 504 (2d Cir. 1994).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Accident victims extensive alcohol consumption was wrongly excluded under rule when it was directly probative of the cause and nature of the accident, and hence was not unfairly prejudicial. Swajian v. Gen. Motors Corp., 916 F.2d 31 (1st Cir. 1990).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A five-year-old drug possession conviction, which resulted in no jail time, tells jurors nothing about the witnesss credibility. At the same time, the likelihood of unfair prejudice was great. Hence it was not error to exclude impeachment based on the drug possession charge. United States v. Galati, 230 F.3d 254 (7th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A drug-related offense cannot be admitted for the sole purpose of making a general character attack. Thus, under Rule 609(a)(2), a nonparty witnesss prior conviction should not have been admitted. United States v. Galati, 230 F.3d 254 (7th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Past drug activity involving co-conspirators tended to show knowledge of how to sell drugs or acquaintance with co-conspirators, and was not barred by Rule 403, as the danger of unfair prejudice was minimal because the testimony at issue was insignificant in comparison to the overwhelming evidence against the defendant. In addition, the testimony had significant probative value in that it enabled the government to give a more complete picture of the events leading up to the formation of the conspiracy. United States v. Brisk, 171 F.3d 514 (7th Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Narcotics dog alert to deck of defendants vessel had substantial probative value where it corroborated law enforcement officers testimony that they had seen narcotics dumped overboard. There was no undue prejudice from this testimony, in the sense of any tendency to lure the fact finder into deciding guilt on an improper basis, commonly though not necessarily an emotional one. United States v. Rosario-Peralta, 199 F.3d 552 (1st Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of defendants drug activities in prior years was properly admitted where the events were within the dates of the charged conspiracy. Such evidence is not Rule 404(b) prior bad acts evidence at all, but evidence that showed defendants initial involvement in the charged conspiracy. The evidence was not offered by the government to prove defendants action in conformity therewith. The testimony is relevant, probative, and not unfairly prejudicial. United States v. Wilson, 177 F.3d 712 (8th Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a marijuana prosecution, evidence that defendant had trafficked in methamphetamine was admissible as it necessarily entails the same knowledge or intent to traffic in marijuana. United States v. Cortinas, 142 F.3d 242 (5th Cir. 1998).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of prior drug transactions was not excludable under Rule 403 since the trial court implicitly conducted the weighing required by the rule. United States v. Jackson, 84 F.3d 1154 (9th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Although remote in time, historical evidence that defendants had been involved in the cultivation and distribution of marijuana in the late 1970s and early 1980s demonstrates a long-standing pattern of drug activity probative with respect to criminal intent and control. United States v. Wacker, No. 93-3372 (10th Cir. filed Dec. 26, 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of narcotic-detecting dog alert to drug traces on defendants currency in a bank was not prejudicial when the dog did not react to other areas of the bank and human senses could detect something unusual about the money. United States v. Saccoccia, 58 F.3d 754 (1st Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reversible error to admit methamphetamine recipes, which by themselves are not closely linked to immediate illegal activity. United States v. Blackstone, 56 F.3d 1143 (9th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 174 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Photographs, Diagrams, and Video Recordings

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Established Doctrine

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Photographic evidence is reviewed under Rule 403. United States v. McCoy, 848 F.2d 743 (6th Cir. 1988); In re Aircrash Disaster Near New Orleans, 767 F.2d 1151 (5th Cir. 1985); Dabney v. Montgomery Ward, 761 F.2d 494 (8th Cir. 1985); United States v. Kilbourne, 559 F.2d 1263 (4th Cir. 1977).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The graphic or disturbing nature of a photograph alone is not enough to render it inadmissible. Rather, the analysis hinges upon whether the photograph is relevant to the resolution of some disputed point in a trial or otherwise aids a jury in a factual determination. United States v. Salim, 189 F. Supp. 2d 93 (S.D.N.Y. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Homicide victim photographs can be highly prejudicial but are admitted within discretion of court. United States v. DeParias, 805 F.2d 1447 (11th Cir. 1986) (decomposing victim); Batchelor v. Cupp, 693 F.2d 859 (9th Cir. 1982); United States v. Kaiser, 545 F.2d 467 (5th Cir. 1977); United States v. Cloudman, 534 F.2d 123 (8th Cir. 1976).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A crime-scene photograph is inadmissible only when the picture is of such gruesome and horrifying nature that its probative value is outweighed by the danger of inflaming the jury. United States v. Pena-Guttierez, 222 F.3d 1080 (9th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Case Applications

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Regarding photographs of murder victims who were shot multiple times by a person involved in an alleged drug trafficking conspiracy with the defendant, the test under Rule 403 is whether the photos would elicit such an emotional response that the jurys attitude toward the defendant would be adversely affected wholly apart from its feelings as to her guilt or innocence of the drug conspiracy with which she was charged. The fact that jurors may, due to the testimony of a survivor of the shootings, have an expectation that the photographs are lurid does not mean that they are not unfairly prejudicial within the intendment of the rule. United States v. Smith, 534 F.3d 1211 (10th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Photographs of bloodied, bullet-ridden bodies and blood-stained clothes are different from testimony describing the nature of the underlying shooting, the shooting itself, and the status of its victims. Such photographs are much more shocking and much more likely to provoke an emotional response. Thus, they would likely have substantially more prejudicial than probative value, particularly where the defendant was never charged with having played any part in the shootings. While evidence of the murders is certainly admissible as evidence tending to establish the existence of a drug trafficking conspiracy involving the shooter and the defendant, graphic evidence that adds nothing to the description of the bullet-ridden bodies established through witness testimony except shock is unfairly prejudicial and inadmissible under Rule 403. United States v. Smith, 534 F.3d 1211 (10th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a trial for supporting a foreign terrorist organization, the probative value of a terrorist-training tape owned by the defendant, which tended to show the defendants knowledge of Hizballahs activities, was not outweighed by the potential for prejudice. United States v. Hammoud, 381 F.3d 316 (4th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a civil action alleging wrongful death of a prison inmate, videotaped interviews with the defendants were not excluded by Rule 403 as they were highly probative of the events surrounding the incident. Estate of Moreland v. Dieter, 395 F.3d 747 (7th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A bank burglary defendant was not unduly prejudiced by admission of photograph, taken at time of arrest, depicting defendant in handcuffs in front of a police car because the jury already knew that the defendant had been arrested on the date in question, and the photograph allowed the jury to match defendant with an eyewitness description. United States v. Allen, 390 F.3d 944 (7th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Admission of photographs of two defendants tattoos and gold teeth, for purpose of demonstrating their gang affiliation, was not unfairly prejudicial in drug conspiracy prosecution

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 175 ======
