                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        as it tended to show evidence of a conspiracy and rebutted the defenses arguments of innocent association. United States v. Suggs, 374 F.3d 508 (7th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a personal injury action arising from an automobile accident, the plaintiff could not display National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) videos depicting crash tests because of many difference between the videos and the accident at issue. Melberg v. Plains Mktg., L.P., 332 F. Supp. 2d 1253 (D.N.D. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a conspiracy to possess stolen goods and possession of stolen goods case, court denied defendants motion in limine to exclude a videotape showing defendants discussion about buying and selling stolen goods with an undercover officer on the grounds that the tape was evidence of uncharged acts intricately connected to the charged offense and that it was also evidence of defendants knowledge and absence of mistake; a cautionary instruction by the court was deemed to be adequate to cure any prejudice that might arise from the jurors viewing the entire tape. United States v. Carson, 2003 WL 22682346 (N.D. Ill. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A video showing masked bandits committing a robbery, where the clothing they were depicted in and the weapons they used were recovered either on them or in their vehicle, that corroborates the witness testimony, is not unfairly prejudicial, misleading, or confusing for a jury. United States v. Curtis, 344 F.3d 1057 (10th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Photographs of mans penis and his masturbating sent to a minor were properly admitted as being more probative than prejudicial, particularly where the defendant alleged entrapment at trial. United States v. Jahner, 72 F. Appx 665 (9th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A sale of guns and drugs that was recorded and videotaped by law enforcement is admissible under Rule 403 because of its high probative valuejust because evidence tends to prove a defendants guilt does not mean he has been prejudiced. United States v. Nesbitt, 57 F. Appx 40 (3d Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A photograph depicting the nature and extent of a victims injuries can certainly be relevant and probative of intent, particularly where a defendant places intent in dispute at trial. United States v. Salim, 189 F. Supp. 2d 93 (S.D.N.Y. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Admission of videotapes and photographs of a drug point in a public housing project and the admission of expert testimony to explain the tapes and photographs did not violate Rule 403. United States v. Hernandez-Vega, 235 F.3d 705 (1st Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Videotapes and photos taken while a defendant was away from a drug transaction site still had probative value, and admission did not violate Rule 403. United States v. Hernandez-Vega, 235 F.3d 705 (1st Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Expert testimony explaining to the jury what videotapes and photos depicted is within the trial courts discretion, which was not abused in allowing an expert to opine that exhibits showed drug transactions taking place, that defendant was in control of the trafficking at the location, and that other gangs steered clear of the operation. United States v. Hernandez-Vega, 235 F.3d 705 (1st Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A nongraphic diagram of a station wagon and its companion testimony were not of a nature likely to unfairly prejudice the jury. United States v. Pena-Guttierez, 222 F.3d 1080 (9th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where it was admitted that marijuana grew wild in the area, a proffered videotape showing wild marijuana growing on some portion of defendants property over a year after the search warrant was executed had little probative value. United States v. Allerheiligen, 2000 U.S. App. LEXIS 18529 (10th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Admission of photographs portraying defendant posing with various assault weapons was consistent with other evidence and provided further support for the conclusion that defendant was an illegal participant in the drug ring. Any potential prejudice stemming from the introduction of this evidence would not have outweighed its probative value. United States v. Hernandez, 2000 U.S. App. LEXIS 262 (4th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a suit for product liability against an automobile manufacturer, photographs of charred bodies are admissible under Rule 403 where they tend to show that burn victims were not killed upon impact of a collision, but were alive at the time the car was engulfed in flames. Busse v. Bayerische Motoren Werke, A.G., 1997 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 2791 (E.D. La. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 176 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A computer-animated videotape demonstrating the operation of an electronic switch was properly found not excludable under Rule 403. In re Air Crash Disaster, 86 F.3d 498 (6th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A fifty-five-inch-high chart listing various burdens of proof in shades of color was excluded as presenting red herrings calculated to distract the jury from fact-finding. United States v. McDade, 1996 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 10896 (E.D. Pa. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        No unfair prejudice from admission of videotape of a marijuana cultivation room that was a component of a conspiracy that the defendant was involved in, even though no evidence tied the defendant to the room itself. United States v. Scott, 64 F.3d 377 (8th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Videotaped robbery simulation found not unduly prejudicial because any differences with the actual burglary affect credibility, not admissibility of the evidence. Persian Galleries, Inc. v. Transcon. Ins. Co., 38 F.3d 253 (6th Cir. 1994).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Determination that a videotape was prejudicial based on the judges personal reaction to it was proper, given the discretion vested in court under this rule. Hurt v. Coyne Cylinder Co., 956 F.2d 1319 (6th Cir. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Court could exclude videotaped copy of deposition already before it in transcribed form without watching the tape first, in determining that the tape would be cumulative and too time-consuming. Windsor Shirt Co. v. N.J. Natl Bank, 793 F. Supp. 589 (E.D. Pa. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Photographs of a decomposing stillborn fetus were properly excluded as inflammatory. Navarro de Cosme v. Hosp. Pavia, 922 F.2d 926 (1st Cir. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Accident reenactment on videotape could be excluded under the rule if there was risk jury would be misled because of different circumstances; characterization of tape as demonstration of abstract scientific principles strains credulity where it appears to be attempted reenactment of fact pattern in suit. Swajian v. Gen. Motors Corp., 916 F.2d 31 (1st Cir. 1990).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Day in the Life films reviewed case-by-case for prejudice, testing accuracy, fairness, use of day-to-day tasks (not improbable tasks), self-serving or staged acts, and the opportunity to cross-examine the victim at trial. Bannister v. Town of Noble, 812 F.2d 1265 (10th Cir. 1987).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Homicide victim photographs can be highly prejudicial but are admitted within discretion of court. United States v. DeParias, 805 F.2d 1447 (11th Cir. 1986) (decomposing victim); Batchelor v. Cupp, 693 F.2d 859 (9th Cir. 1982); United States v. Kaiser, 545 F.2d 467 (5th Cir. 1977); United States v. Cloudman, 534 F.2d 123 (8th Cir. 1976).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Photo apparently depicting matter related to case admitted after explicit 403 weighing. United States v. Blackwell, 694 F.2d 1325 (D.C. Cir. 1982).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Photos of victims permitted in serious criminal cases to show deliberateness and wantonness. United States v. Bowers, 660 F.2d 527 (5th Cir. 1981); State v. Crocker, 435 A.2d 58 (Me. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Demonstrative Items

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Demonstrative evidence is reviewed under Rule 403. Iervolino v. Delta Airlines, 796 F.2d 1408 (11th Cir. 1986); United States v. Wanoskia, 800 F.2d 235 (10th Cir. 1986); In re Air Crash Disaster Near New Orleans, 767 F.2d 1151 (5th Cir. 1985); Field v. Omaha Standard, Inc., 732 F.2d 145 (3d Cir. 1984); Hale v. Firestone Tire & Rubber, 756 F.2d 1322 (8th Cir. 1985); Shipp v. Gen. Motors Corp., 750 F.2d 418 (5th Cir. 1985); United States v. Layton, 767 F.2d 549 (9th Cir. 1985); Osborne v. Wainwright, 720 F.2d 1237 (11th Cir. 1983).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 403 governs in-court demonstrations; similarity must be shown, and misleading implication of scientific basis must be avoided. State v. Philbrick, 436 A.2d 844 (Me. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Undue Delay

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where a series of mini-trials would result were the court to admit vague allegations of discrimination against other individuals, the court properly excludes those statements to avoid confusion and delay. Manuel v. City of Chicago, 335 F.3d 592 (7th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Undue delay or waste of time: Hill v. Bache Halsey Stuart Shields, Inc., 790 F.2d 817 (10th Cir. 1986) (abuse of discretion to exclude, as causing undue delay, evidence of plaintiffs later trading with a broker other than defendant); Shad v. Dean Witter Reynolds, Inc., 799 F.2d 525 (9th Cir. 1986); Diede v. Burlington N. R.R., 772 F.2d 593 (9th Cir. 1985) (explanation

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 177 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        of constructive receipt of benefits not needed); Ellis v. Intl Playtex, 745 F.2d 292 (4th Cir. 1984); United States v. Thompson, 710 F.2d 915 (2d Cir. 1983).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Confusing or Misleading Proof

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that misleads the jury is excludable. Specht v. Jensen, 832 F.2d 1516 (10th Cir. 1987); United States v. Runnels, 833 F.2d 1183 (6th Cir. 1987); Koonce v. Quaker Safety Prods., 798 F.2d 700 (5th Cir. 1986); In re Aircraft Disaster Near Chi., 803 F.2d 304 (7th Cir. 1986); Scott v. Sears, 789 F.2d 1052 (4th Cir. 1986); United States v. Kepreos, 759 F.2d 961 (1st Cir. 1985); United States v. Rouco, 765 F.2d 983 (11th Cir. 1985).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Confusion of the issues warrants exclusion of relevant evidence if admission of the evidence would lead to litigation of collateral issues. United States v. Condon, 720 F.3d 748 (8th Cir. 2013).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Medical experts proffered testimony that defendant threatened to kill the President of United States, was more prejudicial than probative, because defendants subjective intent was not relevant to guilt and thus would have been confusing to jury. United States v. Fuller, 387 F.3d 643 (7th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that Patent and Trademark Office (PTO) had suspended infringement plaintiffs application was properly excluded. The PTOs tentative opinion could have been misunderstood by jury as official government position on issue of confusion. Everest Capital Ltd. v. Everest Funds Mgmt., L.L.C., 393 F.3d 755 (8th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a products liability action against a car manufacturer arising from an auto accident, complaints filed by the plaintiff against the driver and the state were not admissible because they would tend to confuse the jury and encourage them to speculate on whether the other complaints were settled. Svege v. Mercedes-Benz Credit Corp., 329 F. Supp. 2d 285 (D. Conn. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The determination that, in a breach of contract action, the risk of jury confusion outweighed benefit of a cross-examination for bias of one partys attorneys, who testified as lay witnesses on the meaning of contract language, was not an abuse of discretion. Crowe v. Bolduc, 334 F.3d 124 (1st Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where court makes a factual finding that there is no connection between a witnesss testimony and documents sought to be admitted, they can be excluded as misleading. United States v. Pearson, 340 F.3d 459 (7th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When fingerprint reports offered by the defendant might mislead the jury without additional context and expert testimony, then they should be excluded. United States v. Sutton, 337 F.3d 792 (7th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When information a party seeks to introduce on cross-examination to prove bias would unfairly confuse the jury as to the issue at trial, such as when the use of an attorney-fee agreement might confuse the jury about another agreements fee arrangement, it is inadmissible. Crowe v. Bolduc, 334 F.3d 124 (1st Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of crimes other than one on trial may confuse or mislead jury. United States v. Zabaneh, 837 F.2d 1249 (5th Cir. 1988).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Proof of large cash purchases not confusing in drug case. United States v. Wood, 834 F.2d 1382 (8th Cir. 1987).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that confuses issues will be excluded. Locricchio v. Legal Serv. Corp., 833 F.2d 1352 (9th Cir. 1987) (in emotional distress claim, proper to exclude proof that defendant published fact that plaintiffs daughter was raped); Outley v. City of New York, 837 F.2d 587 (2d Cir. 1988) (error to admit evidence of plaintiffs other lawsuits); United States v. Killough, 848 F.2d 1523 (11th Cir. 1988); United States v. 0.161 Acres of Land, 837 F.2d 1036 (11th Cir. 1988); United States v. Flitecraft, 803 F.2d 184 (5th Cir. 1986) (legal articles relied on by party properly excluded); Wilmington v. J.I. Case Co., 793 F.2d 909 (8th Cir. 1986) (statistical evidence in discrimination case about plantwide percentages permissible); Diede v. Burlington N. R.R., 772 F.2d 593 (9th Cir. 1985) (proof on nontaxability of annuity in pay claim excluded to avoid speculation).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Personnel actions re others properly excluded in civil rights action charging dissimilar treatment of plaintiff. Garraghty v. Jordan, 830 F.2d 1295 (4th Cir. 1987).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 178 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Impeachment and Credibility

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The Rule 403 balancing of probative value versus prejudicial effect is an integral step toward a determination of admissibility under Rule 608(b). Thus, if it is uncontroverted that prior accusations made by witnesses were false, then the probative value of the evidence to demonstrate the witnesss lack of truthfulness would increase, for purposes of Rule 608(b) and the danger of jury confusion would decrease, for purposes of Rule 403. However, if the offer of proof regarding the falsity of the witnesss prior accusations was inconclusive and the parties continued to dispute the facts and truth behind each alleged accusation, any attempt to prove up the falsity of the prior accusations would trigger a mini-trial concerning allegations unrelated to the current case, and thus increase the danger of jury confusion and speculation, for purposes of Rule 403. United States v. Frederick, 683 F.3d 913 (8th Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for aggravated sexual abuse in violation of 18 U.S.C. 2241(a), the district court did not abuse its discretion in admitting testimony concerning an exposure incident involving the defendant, who was passed out due to over-consumption of alcohol. Although the defendant may have suffered unfair prejudice as a result of the introduction of this testimony, the evidence was at least somewhat probative of his veracity, and whether the incident actually undermined his credibility by showing an exercise of impaired judgment was reasonably left for the jury to determine. United States v. Cerno, 529 F.3d 926 (10th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Admissibility of evidence concerning a prior conviction under Rule 404(b) is measured under the Rule 403 prong of the Huddleston test, which holds that evidence other crimes, wrongs, or acts is properly admitted when (1) the evidence was offered for a proper purpose under Rule 404(b); (2) the evidence was relevant under Rule 401; (3) the probative value of the evidence was not substantially outweighed by its potential for unfair prejudice under Rule 403; and (4) the trial court instructs the jury to consider the evidence only for the proper purpose for which it was admitted. United States v. Burse, 150 F. Appx 829 (10th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Because of the prejudicial nature of evidence of a defendants prior criminal history, Rule 403 requires a district court to take great care to limit the evidence of previous convictions and avoid unnecessary prejudice to the defendant. United States v. Weiland, 420 F.3d 1062 (9th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for unlawful possession of firearms and ammunition by a convicted felon, it was error under Rule 403 to admit four unredacted records reflecting defendants prior conviction of a felony. The government needed to prove only one prior felony conviction to establish defendants status as a prohibited possessor, and the admission of the second, third, and fourth convictions was more prejudicial than probative in that the large number of convictions, when combined with the fact that the jury viewed them without redacting the nature of the underlying offense, increased the risk of prejudice to the defendant while adding little to the prosecutions case. United States v. Weiland, 420 F.3d 1062 (9th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        District court did not abuse its discretion under Rule 403 by allowing the government to impeach a defense witness by introducing a prior inconsistent statement. Furthermore, the court gave the jury a limiting instruction on the use of impeachment evidence, limited any possible unfair prejudice. United States v. Foster, 376 F.3d 577 (6th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        On direct examination evidence of threats against a witness is of little probative value, but on cross-examination, such evidence may be very probative in demonstrating bias or challenging credibility. United States v. Thomson, 359 F.3d 470 (7th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The probative value of prior inconsistent statements introduced to impeach a partys own witness must be balanced under Rule 403. The prejudicial impact of such statements is less when used by the defense than when the government uses them to impeach a government witness. United States v. Buffalo, 358 F.3d 519 (8th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The probative value of the details of inmates prior felony convictions, which included an attempted murder and statutory rape, was substantially outweighed by the risk of prejudice with respect to the issue of credibility, and thus the impeachment would be limited to the number and timing of inmates convictions, without identification of the specific crimes. Sedney v. Blot, 2003 WL 22839801 (S.D.N.Y. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The probative value of an immigration officers testimony regarding suspicious circumstances and inconsistent answers by defendant during a visit with a sister and brother-in-

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 179 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        law to embassy in Ghana was not outweighed by its potential prejudice in defendants prosecution for conspiracy to distribute and possess with intent to distribute heroin; suspicious circumstances made it less likely that defendant testified truthfully in offering innocent explanations of his frequent trips to Ghana, and inconsistencies in information received by the officer cast a considerable doubt on defendants claims that his trips to Ghana had an innocent immigration-related purpose. United States v. Amadu, 73 F. Appx 488 (2d Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a bank fraud prosecution, court did not abuse its discretion by admitting extrinsic evidence that defendant did not disclose on a corporate bankruptcy petition that payments were made to insiders within one year of bankruptcy filing; the evidence was relevant to prove intent to defraud and refute defendants claim of mistake or accident and was not unduly prejudicial, particularly in light of a cautionary instruction given to the jury. United States v. Sanders, 343 F.3d 511 (5th Cir. 2003).
