                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where evidence of a past sexual offense is equivocal and the past act differs from the charged act in important ways, there is no presumption in favor of admissibility and that the trial court retains significant authority to exclude the proffered evidence under Rule 403. Johnson v. Elk Lake Sch. Dist., 283 F.3d 138 (3d Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The probative value of expert testimony that the plaintiff had a sexually transmitted disease that might have caused the injury at issue was not substantially outweighed by the likelihood that the testimony would cause unfair prejudice to the plaintiff. Baker v. Dalkon Shield Claimants Trust, 156 F.3d 248 (1st Cir. 1998).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that defendant, who had been charged with tax evasion, spent large sums of money in topless nightclubs was properly admitted to counter the defendants assertion that he had not received any of the money from the tax evasion scheme and to show motive for committing the crime. United States v. Powell, 124 F.3d 655 (5th Cir. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Extensive evidence involving defendants role as head of a prostitution ring and his violent actions to exert control inadmissible in prosecution for making interstate threats. United States v. Carter, No. 94 CR 628 (N.D. Ill. Aug. 3, 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence with bizarre sexual overtones was not inadmissible under this rule in a financial fraud case, because it addressed the sham nature of the claimed commercial enterprise. United States v. Joetzki, 952 F.2d 1090 (7th Cir. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        It was not reversible error to exclude inquiry into male witnesss acknowledged fetish for wearing womens underwear. United States v. Masters, 924 F.2d 1362 (7th Cir.), cert. denied, 500 U.S. 919 (U.S. 1991) (details were spicy but peripheral).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Pornography

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Use of encryption techniques to conceal child pornography files on a computer presents a substantial risk of unfair prejudice to defendant because it tends to prove a character for dishonesty and disrespect for the law, which could lead the jury to convict him even if it harbors doubts about whether he committed the charged conduct. The fact that defendant not only possessed child pornography, but also took careful, calculated steps to hide it, suggests that he has a character for secretively flouting rules and social norms. While evidence that defendant possesses this character trait would be damaging in any prosecution, it is especially damaging where the defendant is accused of deviant sexual conduct. United States v. Boyajian, 92 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 145 (C.D. Cal. 2013).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The risk that the jury would use possession of encrypted files to reach a conviction on an improper basis is particularly strong where the material encrypted is child pornography, which courts have recognized as unusually inflammatory evidence that can lead a jury to a conviction regardless of factual guilt. The probative value of such encryption evidence is therefore substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, and should be excluded pursuant to Rule 403. United States v. Boyajian, 92 Fed. R. Evid. Serv. 145 (C.D. Cal. 2013).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a child pornography trial, a defendants offer to stipulate that the pornographic material is illegal does not prevent the government from showing a small percentage of the child pornography to the jury. United States v. Morales-Aldahondo, 524 F.3d 115 (1st Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The government was allowed to introduce twelve photographs and ten video clips of child pornography to prove that a defendant possessed more than three such images. The defendants offer to stipulate to that fact did not make the evidence inadmissible. United States v. Morales-Aldahondo, 524 F.3d 115 (1st Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a case where defendant was convicted of knowingly possessing material that contained images of child pornography and of knowingly receiving obscene pictures, it was not error to admit a small of portion of the pictures depicting child pornography that were found in defendants possession; any potential unfair prejudice to the defendant through

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 194 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        showing the images to jurors did not substantially outweigh the probative value of pictures. United States v. Dodds, 347 F.3d 893 (11th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In child pornography case, trial court did not abuse its discretion in excluding images where the prosecutions expert relied on Tanner Scale methodology to determine the ages of the models. The methodology failed Daubert standards here because (1) the breast stages were not useful because the stage age ranges exceeded the age of eighteen and (2) the pubic hair stages were unable to be applied due to poor image quality and uncertain ethnicity of the models. United States v. Katz, 178 F.3d 368 (5th Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for possession of child pornography, the trial court abused its discretion when it allowed pornographic films portraying children engaged in graphic sexual conduct to be shown to the jury even though the defendant had offered to stipulate that the films were child pornography and had traveled in interstate commerce, and that the box cover in which the films were contained included photographs depicting unclothed children. United States v. Merino-Balderrama, 146 F.3d 758 (9th Cir. 1998).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Possession of male pornography by defendant not unfairly suggestive of homosexuality where evidence relates directly to perpetration of sexual molestation. United States v. Yazzie, 59 F.3d 807 (9th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In child pornography prosecution, unrelated pornography involving adults seized upon defendants arrest should have been excluded under the rule as highly prejudicial and lacking in probative value in the prosecution at hand. United States v. Harvey, 991 F.2d 981 (2d Cir. 1993).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Pornographic pictures were properly admitted despite defendants concession of obscenity. United States v. Gantzer, 810 F.2d 349 (2d Cir. 1987).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Polygraph Evidence

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Mention of polygraph examination could have confused the jury and caused speculation, and hence was properly barred, especially where defendant had ample opportunity to discredit the witnesses testimony and create doubt concerning their credibility. United States v. Robbins, 197 F.3d 829 (7th Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Daubert overruled the bright-line rule that all unstipulated polygraph evidence is inadmissible, and a particularized factual inquiry into scientific validity is required. However, where the record showed lack of a known error rate for real-life polygraph exams, controversy in the relevant scientific community regarding the validity of theoretical basis for the polygraph, and the paucity of controlling standards, exclusion of polygraph evidence was not error. United States v. Cordoba, 194 F.3d 1053 (9th Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reference to polygraph test (not in response to a question) was not automatically basis for mistrial, and significant prejudice was not shown. United States v. Walton, 908 F.2d 1289 (6th Cir. 1990).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Under Daubert, the court must conduct individualized inquiries under Rules 702 and 403 to determine whether unstipulated polygraph evidence is admissible. United States v. Cordoba, 104 F.3d 225 (9th Cir. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Pursuant to Daubert, per se exclusion of polygraph evidence is no longer appropriate. Judges should consider the validity of the procedures used, qualifications of the technician, and other circumstances of the test. United States v. Posado, 57 F.3d 428 (5th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where the polygraph questions asked by the examiner are misleading in the context of the facts of the case on trial, refusal to admit the test is appropriate. United States v. Kwong (2d Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prejudice from polygraph evidence is overstated and should not preclude defendant from using technology to bolster claim of innocence. United States v. Crumby, 895 F. Supp. 1354 (D. Ariz. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Trial court has discretion to exclude polygraph results unilaterally provided by the defense to bolster credibility. United States v. Sherlin, 67 F.3d 1208 (6th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 195 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Money, Jewelry, and General Wealth

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of money packed in dealer folds seized from defendants car, a practice peculiar to drug dealers, was not unduly prejudicial. United States v. Butler, 102 F.3d 1191 (11th Cir. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for various drug trafficking offenses, the probative value of expensive jewelry and currency found on the defendant at the time of arrest is not substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice. United States v. Myrick, 1997 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 13662 (N.D. Ill. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Questions about plaintiffs personal wealth as well as references to plaintiffs religion and unemployment benefits in an age discrimination case combined to constitute plain error because the jury was presented with irrelevant and distracting information. Silbergleit v. First Interstate Bank, 37 F.3d 394 (8th Cir. 1994).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of corporations general size was not erroneously admitted, prior to finding that plaintiff was entitled to recover punitive damages, where the evidence was general and not prejudicial. In re Joint E. & S. Dist. Asbestos Litig., 798 F. Supp. 925 (E.D. & S.D.N.Y. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of former partys financial strength was not prejudicial since that entity indirectly remained a party because of joint venture with defendant. Denison v. Swaco Geolograph Co., 941 F.2d 1416 (10th Cir. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Bench Trials

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The part of Rule 403 that authorizes exclusion of evidence because of its unfair prejudicial impact has no logical relationship to bench trials. Rule 403 assumes a trial judge is able to discern and weigh the improper inferences that a jury might draw from certain evidence, and then balance those improprieties against probative value and necessity. Certainly, in a bench trial, the same judge can also exclude those improper inferences from his mind in reaching a decision. Solis v. Seibert, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11249 (M.D. Fla. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 403 may not apply in bench cases. Gulf States Util. Co. v. Ecodyne Corp., 635 F.2d 517 (5th Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Scientific and Expert Proof

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 403 offers a basis for excluding evidence independent of Rule 702 and Daubert v. Merrell Dow Pharm., Inc., 509 U.S. 579 (1993). Although a consideration of Rule 403 is included in the Daubert analysis, Rules 403 and 702 address different aspects of evidence. United States v. Semrau, 693 F.3d 510 (6th Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 403, which permits excluding otherwise admissible evidence if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, applies to expert testimony, which can be especially powerful and possibly misleading for lay jurors who may tend to overemphasize the importance or value of an experts opinion. Donihe v. Young, 2006 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 88471 (N.D. Ga. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Because most jurors are unfamiliar with the gang trade, it was not unfair prejudice for the governments expert witness to testify on the nature of drug conspiracies in a case alleging membership in a drug-related conspiracy. United States v. Garcia-Morales, 382 F.3d 12 (1st Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a trial of a financial advisor, defendant argued that he was prejudiced by the very impressive credentials of the governments handwriting expert. This was not an unfair prejudice and was outweighed by the experts probative value. United States v. Rutland, 372 F.3d 543 (3d Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Expert evidence based on experimental testing was permissibly excluded because the experiments recreated the cause of the fire at issue without addressing the malfunction of certain parts that was at issue. Firemans Fund Ins. Co. v. Canon U.S.A., Inc., 394 F.3d 1054 (8th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a trial of one gang member where another gang member testified that the weapon in question actually belonged to him, expert proof on the obligations within gangs of junior

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 196 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        members to protect senior members was admissible and not unfairly prejudicial. United States v. Padilla, 387 F.3d 1087 (9th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Although the government may call on law enforcement officials to decipher drug jargon, district courts must ensure the testimony does not stray beyond the scope of the experts expertise. Testimony that goes beyond the witnesss expertise could implicate Rule 403. United States v. Cruz, 363 F.3d 187 (2d Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Drug and Alcohol Use

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Blood alcohol test results, taken two hours after an accident, were admissible under Rule 403 against the driver of a car that killed two people because they were relevant to establish that she committed the crime of driving under the influence of alcohol when the deaths occurred; this probative value was too high to permit exclusion. United States v. First Smoke, 35 F. Appx 337 (9th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Of the plaintiffs four hospitalizations for alcohol abuse, only the one at the time of the events at issue overcomes Rule 403 as evidence that his decision-making abilities at the time were impaired. Conway v. Icahn & Co., 16 F.3d 504 (2d Cir. 1994).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of a prosecution witnesss use of drugs (with one defendant), raised by a defendant, was excluded as possibly prejudicial to other defendants. United States v. Salmon, 944 F.2d 1106 (3d Cir. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Train operator drug test results were highly probative; to minimize potential for jury prejudice, the trial should be bifurcated to resolve the issue of proximate cause first. Johnson v. Wash. Metro. Area Transit Auth., 764 F. Supp. 1568 (D.D.C. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Accident victims extensive alcohol consumption was wrongly excluded under rule when it was directly probative of the cause and nature of the accident, and hence was not unfairly prejudicial. Swajian v. Gen. Motors Corp., 916 F.2d 31 (1st Cir. 1990).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Collateral Matters

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of enforcement actions filed against defendant accounting firm were highly probative of the motive and intent of the firm in subsequently destroying documents; therefore, their probative value was not outweighed by the potential for prejudice. United States v. Arthur Andersen, LLP, 374 F.3d 281 (5th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Excursions into collateral matters may be barred under Rule 403. United States v. Buljubasic, 808 F.2d 1260 (7th Cir. 1987).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Pre- and Post-Suit Evidence

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Admissions in another case may be excluded if not clear and formal. Rowe Intl, Inc. v. J-B Enters., Inc., 647 F.2d 830 (8th Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prior acquittals are usually inadmissible in later civil actions. United States v. Kerley, 643 F.2d 299 (5th Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Fact of prior suit may be admitted to show knowledge of claims. Wilson v. Scripps-Howard Broad. Co., 642 F.2d 371 (6th Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Events before and after accident in suit may be received if sufficiently similar to be relevant. Johnson v. State, 636 P.2d 47 (Alaska 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prior suit may be shown to prove bias. State v. Whitman, 429 A.2d 203 (Me. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Previous claims may be barred if not similar. Smith v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 633 F.2d 40 (5th Cir. 1980).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Consent judgments may be barred in later suit. United States v. Cook, 557 F.2d 1149 (5th Cir. 1977).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Possession of gun, ten weeks after robbery, excluded/admitted. United States v. Robinson, 544 F.2d 611 (2d Cir. 1976), vacated on rehg, 560 F.2d 507 (1977) (en banc).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Letters written after events excluded. United Telecomms., Inc. v. Am. Television Commcns Corp., 536 F.2d 1310 (10th Cir. 1976).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 197 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Unfair Prejudice
