                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Court did not abuse its discretion in admitting as extrinsic evidence, in a prosecution for use of destructive device during a crime of violence stemming from a delivery of booby-trapped explosive package to an individual, portions of a book titled The Anarchist Cookbook, namely the title, the page on which defendants name had been written and the chapter detailing the making of explosives and booby traps; the admitted chapter discussed the same techniques used in the device in question, the book was found in defendants mothers residence which he had visited as recently as three months before the offense, irrelevant portions of the book including the discussions of large building explosions were redacted, and the court gave a limiting instruction permitting the jurors to consider the book only for the purposes of identity, preparation and/or knowledge. United States v. Walters, 351 F.3d 159 (5th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a medical malpractice action, the probative value of testimony from other patients who underwent the same surgery about their results was substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice; the other patients were allowed to testify about what happened prior to their operations, the results of other surgeries had little bearing on whether or not the surgery was considered experimental at the time the plaintiffs underwent the procedure, and the admission of the testimony would have created confusion of issues and undue delay. Cetlinski v. Brown, 91 F. Appx 384 (6th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The probative value of a letter suggesting that an inmate was planning to smuggle drugs into the institution was not substantially outweighed by any risk of unfair prejudice in a civil rights suit alleging that correctional officers used excessive force in extracting inmate from a cell and searching him. Sedney v. Blot, 2003 WL 22839801 (S.D.N.Y. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a drug conspiracy trial, testimony from a police officer that a conspirator expected no favors in return for his information and wanted to make a clean break from the conspiracy was admissible under Rule 403 because of its probative value in making it more probable than not that the co-conspirator withdrew from the conspiracy. United States v. Pimentel-Tafolla, 60 F. Appx 656 (9th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A kidnapping victims grand jury testimony, which is later recanted, is not unduly prejudicial under Rule 403 and is admissible in the criminal trial. United States v. Young, 316 F.3d 649 (7th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A tape recording of a co-defendants telephone threat to harm the children of a witness if he cooperated with the government was not unduly prejudicial and was properly admitted as a statement in furtherance of a drug conspiracy. United States v. Montano-Gudino, 309 F.3d 501 (8th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence in a trial-fixing charge that defendants asked police officers to leave without testifying and that these same officers received gifts for fixing cases was unfairly prejudicial when it spilled over into a mail fraud charge in the same trial because it led the jury to want to punish the defendants for the trial fixing irrespective of their guilt on mail fraud. United States v. Cross, 308 F.3d 308 (3d Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Litigation history concerning police department regulations at issue in a retaliatory discharge case was not admissible under Rule 403. Emmons v. City of Orange, 46 F. Appx 444 (9th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reference at trial to a boat as a go-fast vessel may have been somewhat prejudicial, but was not unfairly so because the phrase was used in the context of testimony meant to show the significance of certain conduct or methods of operation unique to the drug distribution businesstestimony that experienced narcotics agents are permitted to provide. United States v. Tinoco, 304 F.3d 1088 (11th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 208 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testing evidence concerning the racially inflammatory conduct of a loan officer who was not involved in processing the applicants loans was admissible because its probative value as to whether a bank discriminated against applicants was not substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice. Paschal v. Flagstar Bank, 295 F.3d 565 (6th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A drivers license containing address and name information establishing a familial link among defendants was admissible under Rule 403 because the prejudice level was low compared to the high probative value of the evidence since the governments theory was that a drug transaction was a family plan. United States v. Nguyen, 284 F.3d 1086 (9th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        OSHA standards have federal backing and are widely known by lay people and thus a jury will likely give OSHA evidence great weight. Testimony that a manufacturer violated these standards would likely be greatly prejudicial, minimally probative, and could confuse a jury. By-rne v. Liquid Asphalt Sys., Inc., 238 F. Supp. 2d 491 (E.D.N.Y. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a district where often a jury becomes somewhat acquainted with the judges serving on the bench, the prestige of a judges judicial office, and the significance of his judicial robe, testimony from that judge as a character witness should not be admitted under Rule 403 because of the danger of unfair prejudice, misleading the jury, and ultimately, in light of other prestigious character witnesses, the presentation of cumulative character evidence. United States v. Munoz-Franco, 203 F. Supp. 2d 102 (D.P.R. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of unrelated plant closings or product recalls was barred under rule where sausage alleged to have caused plaintiffs injury was not manufactured in those facilities. Verzw-yvelt v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. Co., 175 F. Supp. 2d 881 (W.D. La. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence regarding the condition of defendants property a year after the seizure would likely have confused the issues or misled the jury. United States v. Allerheiligen, 2000 U.S. App. LEXIS 18529 (10th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Extrinsic evidence may not be admitted to impeach a witness on a collateral issue, but a party may offer contradictory evidence where an opponent has placed a matter at issue during direct examination. Hawthorne Educ. Servs. v. Friedman, 2000 U.S. App. LEXIS 14069 (6th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When an adversary testified I know I did wrong. I hurt people, and I regret it, it was not error to allow his opponent to present a letter suggesting that declarant was not truly sorry. Hawthorne Educ. Servs. v. Friedman, 2000 U.S. App. LEXIS 14069 (6th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testimony by a judge and his wife was probative of defendants intent in a bribery case, an element of the charged offense. Their testimony regarding the actual effect of defendants actions may well have been the only evidence the government could present. Whether there are other means of introducing evidence to support the point to which a witness would testify is a factor in assessing the probative value of that witnesss testimony. United States v. Fleming, 215 F.3d 930 (9th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An argument that reports were meant to prejudice the jury, made without reference to Rule 403, did not preserve the objection absent plain error. Here the reports were relevant to a general understanding of the way the parties functioned under the contract and to demonstrate that defendants had a motivation to conceal violations of the contract. Thus, the district court did not abuse its discretion in allowing their admission. Shaw v. AAA Engg & Drafting, Inc., 213 F.3d 519 (10th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A conversation taped under misleading circumstances was excluded in the discretion of the trial judge because it was minimally probative and the misleading aspects were prejudicial. United States v. Barnhill, 2000 U.S. App. LEXIS 4973 (9th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In case alleging physician error during pregnancy and delivery caused cerebral palsy, evidence regarding the minors physical appearance was highly relevant. When proffered evidence relates to the central issue in a case, it is a difficult matter indeed to show that the prejudicial effect of that evidence substantially outweighs its highly probative nature, as Rule 403 requires. Rubert-Torres v. Hosp. San Pablo, Inc., 205 F.3d 472 (1st Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Display of the damaged child to the jury was improperly precluded under the rule, since means existed to minimize any unfair prejudice. Failure to allow the jury to view the child was an abuse of discretion. Rubert-Torres v. Hosp. San Pablo, Inc., 205 F.3d 472 (1st Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 209 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testimony regarding defendants threatening gestures to a witness on the stand in a prior trial was probative of the fact that witnesses feared for their safety as a result of testifying and this probative value substantially outweighs any prejudicial effect. United States v. Rooks, 1999 U.S. App. LEXIS 11045 (6th Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Money laundering is integrally related to the success of a conspiracy to distribute drugs and is highly relevant to the establishment of the drug conspiracy. United States v. Rooks, 1999 U.S. App. LEXIS 11045 (6th Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Admission of T-shirts with gang name possessed by defendant as well as violent language was not unfairly prejudicial, as they were highly probative evidence on the question of defendants membership in the gang. United States v. Gibbs, 174 F.3d 762 (6th Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence relating to claims no longer at issue was irrelevant. Even where there is some potential relevancy, evidence should be excluded where there is an undue tendency for the evidence to suggest a decision on an improper basis. Dethmers Mfg. Co. v. Automatic Equip. Mfg. Co., 1999 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 15981 (N.D. Iowa 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Exclusion of pleadings was proper to avoid confusing the jury in a complex civil case, but parts of the withdrawn pleadings could be used for impeachment purposes. E. Natural Gas Corp. v. ALCOA, 126 F.3d 996 (7th Cir. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Even if a state law construction standard was relevant on the meaning of a similar OSHA standard, discussion of state law would seriously mislead the jury and confuse the issues. United States v. Pitt Des Moines, Inc., 1997 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 11499 (N.D. Ill. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The potential for confusion outweighed the probative value associated with defendants use of an unofficial transcript of testimony given by a police officer at a suppression hearing to impeach the testimony of the police officer. United States v. Cody, 114 F.3d 772 (8th Cir. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for willfully making false entries in a union ledger, testimony by defendants expert witness that she had a weak grasp of bookkeeping principles (from which the jury could infer that she lacked the necessary mens rea) was not disproportionately compelling and thus not unduly prejudicial to the governments case. United States v. Morales, 108 F.3d 1031 (9th Cir. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for murder, defendant was not unfairly prejudiced by courts decision to admit a scale model of the murder scene and allow it to be taken into the jury room. United States v. Salerno, 108 F.3d 730 (7th Cir. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 403 did not require exclusion of how to books seized in defendants premises, where the books explained how to manufacture illegal drugs. United States v. Kime, 99 F.3d 870 (8th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Membership in a motorcycle gang was not so prejudicial that refusal to bar such evidence under Rule 403 was error. United States v. Irvin, 87 F.3d 860 (7th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Vicious, vulgar threats in a letter and telephone call were not excludable under the rule since they bore on the defendants intent. United States v. Hayden, 85 F.3d 153 (4th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of practices and beliefs of cult not unduly prejudicial when religious teachings used to justify criminal acts. United States v. Beasley, 72 F.3d 1518 (11th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Necessity to provide motive and context for killings of white people justifies admission of racist views held by defendant. United States v. Beasley, 72 F.3d 1518 (11th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In an action against a policeman for excessive use of force, reversible error to exclude evidence because of unfair prejudice that the defendant had been subject to two suspensions from the police force where the defendant claims that his service on the force has been uninterrupted. Westcott v. Crinklaw, 68 F.3d 1073 (8th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In litigation arising from a plane crash, FAA reports detailing a single incident of falsifying flight logs by defendant proffered to indict the credibility of payroll records kept by other employees of an air company inadmissible because FAA investigation might incite jury to feel hostile towards the falsifier. Firemens Fund Ins. Co. v. Thien, 63 F.3d 754 (8th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of a pricing scheme in Alaska excluded in a case concerning crude oil prices in California because of the complexity of the proof and the probable consumption of limited judicial resources. City of Long Beach v. Standard Oil Co., 46 F.3d 929 (9th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 210 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testimony that defendant headed a gang, employed security guards, and had survived two attempts on his life in the previous year admissible in prosecution for unlawful possession of a firearm by a felon. United States v. Lloyd, No. 94-3665 (7th Cir. Dec. 5, 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Letter written by defendant glorifying killing and comparing himself with Jeffrey Dahmer is likely to inflame the jury and is inadmissible in prosecution for attempting to assassinate the president. United States v. Duran, 884 F. Supp. 534 (D.D.C. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that the hand brake that allegedly injured the plaintiff functioned properly before and after the time of the accident was not prejudicial. Richardson v. Consol. Rail Corp., 17 F.3d 213 (7th Cir. 1994).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The fact that an inmates original destination on the date of incident was mental health clinic was not prejudicial and was admissible, especially since portions of the inmates psychiatric history itself were admissible. Lewis v. Velez, 149 F.R.D. 474 (S.D.N.Y. 1993).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Exclusion of proof of violence between husband and wife, in an action to collect insurance proceeds after the husband died allegedly by the wifes hand, was not prejudicial error. Hastings v. Bos. Mut. Life Ins. Co., 975 F.2d 506 (8th Cir. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of carcinogenic traits of types of asbestos was admissible even in the absence of proof about the presence of specific forms of asbestos in products involved in the litigation. Blancha v. Raymark Indus., 972 F.2d 507 (3d Cir. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Court properly excluded evidence mentioning cancer in asbestos case where no satisfactory proof was offered of likelihood plaintiff would contract the disease. OBanion v. Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp., 968 F.2d 1011 (10th Cir. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Government safety report dating from more than a year after the accident in suit, making gratuitous criticisms of defendant railroads accident rate and not addressing causation of the accident in question, was properly excluded given its marginal relevance and clear prejudice. Gehl v. Soo Line R.R., 967 F.2d 1204 (8th Cir. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The prejudicial effect of evidence of plaintiffs prior psychiatric treatment did not outweigh probative value of this evidence where plaintiff claimed damages from mental anguish, anxiety, depression, and humiliation. Hancock v. Hobbs, 967 F.2d 462 (11th Cir. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of only marginal relevance that could have confused the jury about a prior ruling of the judge was properly excluded under this rule. DeNieva v. Reyes, 966 F.2d 480 (9th Cir. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of a plaintiffs mental illness was properly excluded under this rule in a police brutality case because of the risk that the jury would impermissibly presume that the afflicted person asked for harsh treatment. Wallace v. Mulholland, 957 F.2d 333 (7th Cir. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Exclusion of a civil judgment not yet final, in an effort to prove a predicate act under RI-CO, was proper under the rule, since the potential for prejudice was great and the probative value of the other litigation was limited. Harrell v. DCS Equip. Leasing, 951 F.2d 1453 (5th Cir. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The trial court did not abuse its discretion in excluding jail standards from evidence in a civil rights action, because admitting the standards would tend to mislead and confuse the jury as to the relevant standard of conduct. Johnson v. Busby, 953 F.2d 349 (8th Cir. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Excluding evidence that the defendant police department had initially wanted a SWAT team to serve the search warrant was not an abuse of discretion, since the evidence implied that the plaintiffs were especially dangerous. Larez v. City of Los Angeles, 946 F.2d 630 (9th Cir. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Admission of a life-size model was not unfairly prejudicial. Roland v. Langlois, 945 F.2d 956 (7th Cir. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Possibility of jury confusion over differing government reports was insufficient to warrant exclusion. Moss v. Ole S. Real Estate, Inc., 933 F.2d 1300 (5th Cir. 1991); FDIC v. Clark, 768 F. Supp. 1402 (D. Colo. 1989) (actual settlement agreement would have injected collateral matters and been too confusing).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        No abuse of discretion to exclude evidence of past disciplinary action against police officer. Donald v. Rast, 927 F.2d 379 (8th Cir. 1991); Berkovich v. Hicks, 922 F.2d 1018 (2d Cir. 1991) (admitting prior complaints against officer, who had been exonerated on all but one complaint, would only inflame the situation).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 211 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence explaining the effects of alcohol impairment on a driver may be unfavorable to a party but is not unfair prejudice as contemplated in the rule. McEwen v. City of Norman, 926 F.2d 1539 (10th Cir. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Limiting instruction mitigated risk that agents acknowledged consultation with five lawyers would highlight defendants resources. Sweeney v. Westvaco, 926 F.2d 29 (1st Cir. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Even if evidence of alleged defects in other batches of the product were relevant, the ancillary question of the similarity of the batches is too confusing and time-consuming. Blue Circle Atl., Inc. v. Falcon Materials, Inc., 760 F. Supp. 516 (D. Md. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Admitting EEOC probable cause determination is highly prejudicial where plaintiff had not given personal statement. Cortes v. Maxus Exploration Co., 758 F. Supp. 1182 (S.D. Tex. 1991); Dickerson v. State of N.J., Dept of Human Servs., 767 F. Supp. 605 (D.N.J. 1991) (absent showing of untrustworthiness, preliminary EEOC determination admissible).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        References to Jamaicans taking over drug trade in the locality should have been excluded in prosecution of person from Jamaica, as inviting racial or ethnic bias. United States v. Doe, 903 F.2d 16 (D.C. Cir. 1990).
