                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A defendants denial of ever engaging in conduct such as was charged made proof of similar event a few months earlier admissible. United States v. Rodriguez, 31 M.J. 150 (C.M.A. 1990).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Weighing of prejudiciality of prior-crimes evidence may require objection or motion of the aggrieved party. United States v. Acosta-Cazares, 878 F.2d 945 (6th Cir. 1989).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Possession of bomb supplies is admissible since this is not itself a crime. United States v. Bagaric, 706 F.2d 42 (2d Cir. 1983).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where Rule 404(b) applies, court must still articulate a Rule 403 balance favoring admission of the evidence. United States v. Robinson, 700 F.2d 205 (5th Cir. 1983).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Earlier portions of a single series of transactions may be admitted without regard to Rule 404(b). United States v. Torres, 685 F.2d 921 (5th Cir. 1982) (pilot buys leading to large narcotics transaction admitted); United States v. Wooten, 688 F.2d 941 (4th Cir. 1982) (complete story of a conspiracy may be proved).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prior misconduct of others, even in same business, may not be admitted under 404(b). United States v. Angelilli, 660 F.2d 23 (2d Cir. 1981).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Unrelated prior crimes are usually not admissible. United States v. Bettencourt, 614 F.2d 214 (9th Cir. 1980); United States v. James, 555 F.2d 992 (D.C. Cir. 1977); United States v. McFayden-Snider, 522 F.2d 1178 (6th Cir. 1977).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Conduct of others cannot be used against a witness or party to attack character. United States v. Ochoa, 609 F.2d 198 (5th Cir. 1980).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Possession of contraband may show opportunity to sell under 404(b). United States v. Fairchild, 526 F.2d 185 (7th Cir. 1975).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Identity

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A note with a cocaine-cutting recipe found in defendants car when he was arrested was proper evidence of defendants mental state, although it could not properly have been received on the issue of defendants identity. United States v. Edwards, 342 F.3d 168 (2d Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Simply because the defense has put knowledge, intent or identity in issue does not open the door for the government and give it carte blanche to introduce any prior act of defendant that falls into the same crime category. Rather, some similarity or tangible connection between the acts must be identified, something that makes the prior act relevant to proving the contested fact. United States v. Edwards, 342 F.3d 168 (2d Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testimony from two prostituteseach of whom witnessed a robbery charged in the indictmentthat defendant had previously paid them to engage in sexual acts showed the prostitutes familiarity with defendant, and hence their ability to identify him, a plainly disputed issue in the case because defendant proffered a witness who testified that another man had been robbing prostitutes customers during the relevant periodimplying that the prosecution witnesses had mistaken that person for defendant. Since Rule 404(b) expressly permits the admission of other crimes evidence to prove identity, the district court did not err in admitting the testimony. United States v. Pindell, 336 F.3d 1049 (D.C. Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 242 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Motive

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Established Doctrine

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence not part of the crime charged but pertaining to the chain of events explaining the context, motive and set-up of the crime is properly admitted if linked in time and circumstances with the charged crime, or forms an integral and natural part of an account of the crime, or is necessary to complete the story of the crime for the jury. United States v. Potts, 132 F. Appx 330 (11th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of past activity that suggests motive may be admissible. The closer in time the events, the more past activities have probative value. United States v. Mahone, 328 F. Supp. 2d 77 (D. Me. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Unlike knowledge and intent, motive is not an element of the crime that the government must prove. For that reason, proof of motive must be offered to show some other element, for example, that the crime was committed, the identity of the accused, or the accuseds requisite mental state. United States v. Varoudakis, 233 F.3d 113 (1st Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When prior-bad-act evidence is offered to prove a motive for the crime, courts must be on guard to prevent the motive label from being used to smuggle forbidden evidence of propensity to the jury. The tool for preventing this abuse is Rule 403. United States v. Varoudakis, 233 F.3d 113 (1st Cir. 2000); United States v. Cunningham, 103 F.3d 553 (7th Cir. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        To prove motive, an other crime, wrong, or act need not be similar to offense with which defendant is charged. United States v. Cyphers, 553 F.2d 1064 (7th Cir. 1977); United States v. Johnson, 542 F.2d 230 (5th Cir. 1976); United States v. Johnson, 525 F.2d 999 (2d Cir. 1975).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Motive for the conduct alleged in the present case may be shown by prior actions of the defendant. United States v. Horton, 847 F.2d 313 (6th Cir. 1988); United States v. Shriver, 842 F.2d 968 (7th Cir. 1988); United States v. Bailey, 834 F.2d 218 (1st Cir. 1987); Cerro Gordo Charity v. Firemans Fund Am. Life Ins., 819 F.2d 1471 (8th Cir. 1987) (numerous insurance policies admitted to show motive to cause death); United States v. Everett, 825 F.2d 658 (2d Cir. 1987); United States v. Holt, 817 F.2d 1264 (7th Cir. 1987) (stolen checks admitted to show dire straits as motive for bank robbery); Aetna Cas. & Sur. Co. v. Gosdin, 803 F.2d 1153 (11th Cir. 1986) (prior burglary and pimping activities improperly admitted to show motive (need) in arson/insurance action); United States v. Buchanan, 787 F.2d 477 (10th Cir. 1986); United States v. Feldman, 788 F.2d 544 (9th Cir. 1986); Roshan v. Ford, 705 F.2d 102 (4th Cir. 1983); United States v. Reed, 717 F.2d 1481 (4th Cir. 1983).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Case Applications

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 404(b) permits admission of evidence of a defendants prior bad acts to prove intent and motive. To be admissible, however, the evidence must be similar in kind and reasonably close in time to the crime charged. Moreover, the prosecution must present sufficient evidence from which a jury could find by a preponderance of the evidence that the prior act occurred. United States v. Tarnow, 705 F.3d 809 (8th Cir. 2013).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The similar-in-kind requirement is less important in determining the admissibility of prior-acts evidence under Rule 404(b) when the evidence is used to establish motive as compared to knowledge or the other categories of permissible purposes the rule recognizes. For example, prior domestic-abuse evidence may be admitted to prove motive for arson. United States v. Tyerman, 701 F.3d 552 (8th Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for conspiracy and murder of a witness to prevent him from testifying against one of the defendants in an upcoming state court murder trial, testimony that this defendant shot another person on the same street block where the victim was killed was properly admitted as evidence of other crimes under Rule 404(b) as demonstrating that the shootings were related to retaining this defendants drug turf and suggested a common theme to the two shootings. Further, the evidence was relevant to firearms offenses, it was necessary to address issues of identity and credibility, and its admission was not unduly prejudicial under Rule

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 243 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        403 since the district court provided two curative instructions. United States v. Byers, 649 F.3d 197 (4th Cir. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When the evidence presented to the jury generates uncertainty about motive or identity, resort to other-crimes evidence may be appropriate. United States v. Byers, 649 F.3d 197 (4th Cir. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for preparing and filing false tax returns Rule 404(b) did not prohibit testimony from clients about their dealings with defendant when their experiences did not form one of the underlying counts of the indictment, because the testimony went to the non-propensity purpose of demonstrating motive, voluntariness, and lack of mistake, as well as providing background information. United States v. Okorie, 425 F. Appx 166 (3d Cir. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a case charging drug possession and distribution, evidence of defendants later, similar crime was admissible to show motive under Rule 404(b). United States v. Davis, 636 F.3d 1281 (10th Cir. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testimony about prior but differing instances of racial discrimination does not constitute a habit or routine and is thus not admissible under Rule 406. However, such evidence is admissible to prove a motive, intent, or plan to discriminate pursuant to 404(b). Goldsmith v. Bagby Elevator Co., 2008 WL 150585 (11th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Legitimate evidence of motive, where that issue is pertinent, is admissible under the plain language of Rule 404(b), even where it consists of other crimes, wrongs, or acts, and evidence of income patterns is recognized as relevant to demonstrate a motive of financial gain. United States v. Bates, 146 F. Appx 795 (6th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where the defendant kidnapped a postal employee with the intent of using the employee to gain access to his girlfriends home, evidence of prior occasions where he had threatened his girlfriend were admissible to show his motive behind the kidnapping. United States v. Abraham, 386 F.3d 1033 (11th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a trial for felon in possession of a firearm, evidence of the defendants general drug activities were admissible to show motive, knowledge, and lack of mistake. United States v. Brown, 345 F. Supp. 2d 358 (S.D.N.Y. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        District court abused its discretion by admitting a prior conviction without an articulated reason. Evidence of gang involvement occurring during incarceration might have some probative value for motive to commit to the crimes now charged, but evidence of events giving rise to the incarceration was largely prejudicial. The government could have made a compelling argument that the disputed evidence showed intent, but did not do so before or at trial. United States v. Crenshaw, 359 F.3d 977 (8th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that defendant had committed prior acts of sexual conduct with minors was admissible to show motive, intent, knowledge, plan, preparation and lack of mistake on the date in question. United States v. Breitweiser, 357 F.3d 1249 (11th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of past activity that suggests motive may be admissible. In this case, the fact that defendant lost money he was supposed to deposit in a companys lockbox may provide evidence of motive for stealing money in order to replace the lost deposit. United States v. Mahone, 328 F. Supp. 2d 77 (D. Me. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Other acts of discrimination identical to the kind charged were admissible to prove the motive or intent, the testimony had a substantial probative value because it was related to another instance of potential race discrimination in filling a position by the same person making the selections at issue, and there was no risk of unfair prejudice to the government since the director was permitted by courts questioning to give the fullest possible explanation for the selection he made. Allen v. Perry, 279 F. Supp. 2d 36 (D.D.C. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of drug activities was admissible to show the defendants motive for illegal possession of a firearm. United States v. Bryan, 53 F. Appx 590 (2d Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a kidnapping case in which defendant himself opened the door on cross-examination by referring to prior abduction incidents, evidence on these matters was properly admitted to show plan and motive, and to rebut defendants alleged belief that the abduction was actually a consensual vacation. United States v. Powell, 42 F. Appx 565 (4th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 244 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A prior drug conviction was usable to show defendants motive for not having drug paraphernalia at his house and relevant in explaining his motive in not leaving any trash on curb. United States v. Roe, 210 F.3d 741 (7th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Reference to separate indictment for extortion was permissible to explain issues raised in defense examination of a witness, and to explain an attempted murder. United States v. Balsam, 203 F.3d 72 (1st Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Trial court did not err in admitting testimony of a prior conviction (subject to a limiting instruction) because it established one of defendants motives for falsifying a passport application (the charged crime) was to avoid discovery of the prior conviction in his real name. United States v. Polydoor, 1999 U.S. App. LEXIS 18294 (9th Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Solicitation of another to commit bank robbery was relevant to show motive for bank robbery: defendant thought this was a quick and easy way to solve his financial problems. United States v. Robinson, 177 F.3d 643 (7th Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Being poor is not a crime, wrong, or act. Rule 404(b) therefore has no application to admission of evidence of defendants poverty to show motive. United States v. Mitchell, 172 F.3d 1104 (9th Cir. 1999).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that defendants had previously stolen items from the site of an arsonous fire to trade for crack cocaine was admissible as relevant to motive. United States v. Edwards, 159 F.3d 1117 (8th Cir. 1998).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The greater the overlap between propensity and motive, the more careful the district judge must be about admitting under the rubric of motive evidence that the jury is likely to use instead as a basis for inferring the defendants propensity, his habitual criminality, even if instructed not to. United States v. Cunningham, 103 F.3d 553 (7th Cir. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Use of drugs by an alleged bank robber was admissible to prove motive. United States v. Brooks, 125 F.3d 484 (7th Cir. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of defendants addiction to Demerol was admissible to show motive for stealing Demerol. United States v. Cunningham, 103 F.3d 553 (7th Cir. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for bank robbery, evidence of defendants use of crack cocaine and their desire to obtain more cocaine was admissible to show their motive for the bank robbery. United States v. Treesh, 125 F.3d 484 (7th Cir. 1997).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that the purpose or motive for the kidnapping was for companionship or sexual assault of the victim was properly received. United States v. Sriyuth, 98 F.3d 739 (3d Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Sexual assault evidence was probative of motive as well as the victims nonconsent to interstate transportation and, therefore, was admissible under Rule 404(b) since the probative value of the sexual assault evidence outweighed the risk of undue prejudice. United States v. Sriyuth, 98 F.3d 739 (3d Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testimony of morally offensive conduct, otherwise admissible under this rule, is not unfairly prejudicial if it shows motive for the crime charged. United States v. Aramony, 88 F.3d 1369 (4th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a gun possession case, amphetamine recipes and private drug paraphernalia were not admissible to show motive for gun possession. United States v. Blackstone, 56 F.3d 1143 (9th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a bank robbery case, evidence of cocaine use by the defendant was inadmissible to show motive without evidence that the drug use was significant and that defendant suffered from financial need. United States v. Madden, 38 F.3d 747 (4th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In murder trial in which the prosecution argued that the deceased had threatened to disclose the defendants prior record and other abuses of children, evidence of prior conviction for sexual exploitation of child admitted to show motive. United States v. Menzer, 29 F.3d 1223 (7th Cir. 1994).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Though not necessarily involving the defendants, evidence of murders between rival factions of a crime family admitted to show motivation and to demonstrate the existence of a violent internal war. United States v. Brady, 26 F.3d 282 (2d Cir. 1994).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A defendants drug use was inadmissible where there was no evidence of financial need supplying a motive for a bank robbery. United States v. Madden, 38 F.3d 747 (4th Cir. 1994).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 245 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Absent material issue on motive (or other permissible Rule 404(b) issue), prior drug use was inadmissible. United States v. Sutton, 41 F.3d 1257 (8th Cir. 1994).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A $30-a-day heroin habit was admissible to demonstrate motive to commit a bank robbery. United States v. Miranda, 986 F.2d 1283 (9th Cir. 1993).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        While Rule 404(b) allows evidence of prior bad acts as proof of motive, that would not include a motive to testify falsely. United States v. Farmer, 923 F.2d 1557 (11th Cir. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A prior arrest may show motive and bias. Pittsley v. Warish, 927 F.2d 3 (1st Cir. 1991) (prior arrest to show motive and bias); . 1In re Korean Airlines Disaster of Sept, 1983, 932 F.2d 1475 (D.C. Cir. 1991) (prior airline incidents to show knowledge); United States v. 890 Noyac Rd., 945 F.2d 1252 (2d Cir. 1991) (taped conversation to show knowledge).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Financial distress was relevant on motive to accept a bribe. United States v. McMahon, 938 F.2d 1501 (1st Cir. 1991).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Since motive is not an element for most offenses, some courts state that evidence of prior acts to show motive are admissible only if relevant to establish a contested issue of specific intent to commit the crime charged. United States v. Farmer, 923 F.2d 1557 (1st Cir. 1991); United States v. Brown, 873 F.2d 1265 (9th Cir. 1989).
