                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Other offenses that form part of a common plan or scheme of which the charged offense is allegedly a part need not be especially similar to offense charged. United States v. Barrett, 539 F.2d 244 (1st Cir. 1976).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Case Applications

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence establishing defendants involvement in an ongoing drug trafficking conspiracy was intrinsic to the current charge for purposes of Rule 404(b). The evidence about prior incidents was offered, and admitted, to show how defendant kept the worker-bees in line with respect to the drug trafficking organization and the kind of organizational control he exercised, which were facts placed in issue by his defense that there was no organized enterprise at all and that, to the extent that a narcotics conspiracy existed, it was made up of equals, of which he was but one. United States v. Mahdi, 598 F.3d 883 (D.C. Cir. 2010).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for coercing Jamaican immigrants into forced labor, evidence that the defendant had on a prior occasion intimidated and attempted to isolate other employees was admissible for showing that there was a deliberate scheme to commit the same acts with respect to the prosecuting victims. United States v. Bradley, 390 F.3d 145 (1st Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of other crimes or wrongs may be admitted if there is sufficient evidence from which the jury could conclude, by a preponderance, that the defendant committed the prior wrongs. In this arson case, evidence of other fires similar to the ones charged that took place on defendants property was admissible to show common plan or scheme. United States v. Decicco, 370 F.3d 206 (1st Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        What matters is that the evidence be relevant to show a pattern of operation that would suggest intent and that tends to undermine the defendants innocent explanation. Admissible bad-acts evidence need not show incidents identical to the events charged, so long as they are closely related to the offense, and are probative of intent rather than mere propensity. United States v. Long, 328 F.3d 655 (D.C. Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testimony of two minors met the threshold level of similarity to the charged events and tended to establish that defendants pattern of ingratiation was animated by an intent to engage in sexual contact. As such, the testimony of the two minors was admissible for a proper purpose under Rule 404(b). United States v. Long, 328 F.3d 655 (D.C. Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a drug conspiracy case, defendants possession and distribution of cocaine about two years after the last overt act in furtherance of the alleged conspiracy was properly proven under the rule on the issues of plan and intent. United States v. Dickerson, 248 F.3d 1036 (1st Cir. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The plan and identity uses of Rule 404(b) evidence are distinct from each other and from use of prior acts to show knowledge and intent. In drug distribution cases, for example, knowledge and intent are often contested facts proven in part through prior bad acts. United States v. Carroll, 207 F.3d 465 (8th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a conspiracy case, evidence of drug seizures and a controlled sale of narcotics involving defendant, five and ten years prior to the present charges was not barred by Rule 404(b) because

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 270 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        the evidence constitutes a continuing pattern of illegal activity. United States v. Buchanan, 213 F.3d 302 (6th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Tools of the criminal trade of professional robbers, such as ski masks, bullets, a blue police emergency light, and police uniforms were properly admitted under the rule. United States v. Mojica-Baez, 229 F.3d 292 (1st Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prior drug sales by one defendant and prior seizure of drug from second defendant were admissible to show a continuing pattern of illegal activity. United States v. Buchanan, 207 F.3d 344 (6th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of sexual abuse of another child at a different time was too remote to address plan or common scheme theories. United States v. LeCompte, 99 F.3d 274 (8th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Abuse of twelve women could be considered part of a common plan. United States v. Roberts, 88 F.3d 872 (10th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Absent a detailed submission, a hearing on common-plan proof may be required to weigh admissibility of the evidence. United States v. Roberts, 88 F.3d 872 (10th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A detailed comprehension of proposed testimony, trial context, and effects of the proof may be required to rule on objections under Rules 403 and 404(b), which may require evidence on the issues. United States v. Roberts, 88 F.3d 872 (10th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Seven other bank robberies were admissible to address a common plan or scheme where all characteristics in common with the crime charged, tending to show that defendant participated in all eight crimes as part of larger scheme. United States v. McGuire, 27 F.3d 457 (10th Cir. 1994).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where there is evidence that a defendant engaged in a pattern of similar crimes, proof thereof is admissible to establish participation in the scheme now on trial. Amendolare v. Schenkers Intl Forwarders, 747 F. Supp. 162 (E.D.N.Y. 1990).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prior similar bribe admitted to show plan. United States v. Means, 695 F.2d 811 (5th Cir. 1983).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Plan or scheme may be shown with evidence of other crimes. United States v. Calvert, 523 F.2d 895 (8th Cir. 1975).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Distinctive Prior Acts to Prove Identity; Modus Operandi

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Established Doctrine

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Other-crimes evidence under Rule 404(b) need only be of a signature quality when being introduced for the purpose of proving identity by modus operandi. Along these lines, the other crimes must be highly similar to the crime charged, but they need not be identical to the crime charged. United States v. Mares, 441 F.3d 1152 (10th Cir. 2006); United States v. LaFlora, 146 F. Appx 973 (10th Cir. 2005); United States v. Smith, 103 F.3d 600 (7th Cir. 1996); United States v. Miller, 883 F.2d 1540 (11th Cir. 1989); United States v. Myers, 550 F.2d 1036 (5th Cir. 1977); United States v. Foutz, 540 F.2d 733 (4th Cir. 1976).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        To admit evidence on a signature facts or modus operandi theory, the trial court must make a threshold determination that a reasonable juror could find from a comparison of the facts that the same person committed both crimesthat is, in making this determination, the court should consider both the distinctiveness of the facts that make the crimes unique and the distance between the crimes in space and in time. Where the prior and present offenses do not involve distinctive characteristics, no inference that the perpetrators were the same arises. United States v. Oman, 427 F.3d 1070 (8th Cir. 2005); United States v. Burnette, 1999 U.S. App. LEXIS 7403 (6th Cir. 1999); United States v. Powell, 587 F.2d 443 (9th Cir. 1978).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 271 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Case Applications

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In order to be admissible under Rule 404(b), when extrinsic offense evidence is introduced to prove identity, the likeness of the offenses is the crucial consideration. The physical similarity must be such that it marks the offenses as the handiwork of the accused. In other words, the evidence must demonstrate a modus operandi. The extrinsic act must be a signature crime, and the defendant must have used a modus operandi that is uniquely his. United States v. Whatley, 719 F.3d 1206 (11th Cir. 2013).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Although not listed in Rule 404(b)s nonexclusive list of proper purposes, modus operandi evidence is normally admitted pursuant to the identity exception. But evidence of modus operandi must be unique; the government must establish not only that the extrinsic act bears some peculiar or striking similarity to the charged crimes, but also that it is the defendants trademark, so unusual and distinctive as to be like a signature. United States v. Burwell, 642 F.3d 1062 (D.C. Cir. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The use of violence and weapons in conjunction with the commission of carjacking and vehicle theft is, unfortunately, not so unique to crimes in the District of Columbia that it constitutes appropriate modus operandi evidence. United States v. Burwell, 642 F.3d 1062 (D.C. Cir. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a carjacking and bank robbery prosecution, it was not error to admit testimony regarding a separate incident in which defendant brandished a similar, if not the same, firearm utilized in the bank robberies. The testimony was relevant as it established a similarity between the other act and the charged offense as to the type of gun that was used, and the probative value of the evidence was not substantially outweighed by its undue prejudice. United States v. Emanuel, 422 F. Appx 760 (11th Cir. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A much greater degree of similarity between the charged crime and the uncharged crime is required when the evidence of the other crime is introduced under Rule 404(b) to prove identity than when it is introduced for another of the myriad reasons allowable under the rule. United States v. Snell, 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 77740 (E.D. Pa. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The fact that in two different bank robberies, a group of robbers forced a teller to enter the bank at gunpoint, ordered the teller to turn off the alarm system, used the teller to access the vault, and made him lie on the ground before the robbers escaped is sufficient evidence to prove a single modus operandi in the two crimes. Thus evidence of the earlier robbery is admissible in a trial for the later robbery. United States v. Price, 516 F.3d 597 (7th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a bank robbery case, the threshold test for admission on a modus operandi theory was met where the prior offenses and charged offenses were robberies of branches of same bank located in suburban grocery stores, in all four robberies the teller was given bag in which to place the money, no weapon or face covering was used in any of the robberies, and only seven years separated the prior robberies and charged offenses. United States v. Oman, 427 F.3d 1070 (8th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that guards beat other inmates in the aftermath of the incident being tried was admissible in order to show pattern and modus operandi on the part of the transporting guards. Surprenant v. Rivas, 424 F.3d 5 (1st Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a trial for five counts of bank robbery, had the counts been severed into separate trials, Rule 404(b) would have allowed evidence of the other counts to be admitted as proof of identity and modus operandi evidence. United States v. Carr, 373 F.3d 1350 (D.C. Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A fraudulent student loan application by defendant using a particular mans signature was properly admitted to show identity of the defendant, who allegedly used the same mans signature in completing the charged fraud on trial. The evidence was relevant to show her modus operandi in her fraudulent schemes. United States v. Huddy, 62 F. Appx 903 (10th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a taxi robbery case, prior crimes similar in kind and not overly remote in time to the charged crime were admissible to show mode of operation under Rule 404(b): Defendant robbed cab drivers with the aid of a knife six times in twenty years, sixteen of which were spent in custody. United States v. Williams, 308 F.3d 833 (8th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of prior drug smuggling in which the defendant concealed cocaine in the wheel wells of his truck was admissible to show that defendant knew drugs were concealed in the gas tank

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 272 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        and that he intended and planned to transport drugs in a hidden spot outside the vehicles passenger compartment. United States v. Sacucedo-Munoz, 307 F.3d 344 (5th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testimony of former investors and business associates claiming to have been defrauded in a similar manner by the defendant was admissible under Rule 404(b) in an investment fraud case to show modus operandi and lack of mistake. United States v. Cassidy, 48 F. Appx 428 (4th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testimony regarding knowledge of violent debt collection and illegal pawn shop activities with respect to gun sales was inextricably intertwined with the crime of illegal firearm possession and admissible under Rule 404(b) to refute a defendants theory that he did not regularly traffic in firearms. United States v. Hernandez, 39 F. Appx 365 (7th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Robbery and assault of a dentist and patients on the day after defendant allegedly robbed a postal inspector of property while the victim was a patient at another dentists office was admissible to show modus operandi. United States v. Martinez-Cin-tron, 136 F. Supp. 2d 14 (D.P.R. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Late disclosure of expected evidence of defendants prior marijuana distribution was not grounds to exclude the evidence where the evidence was not available to the prosecution until the night before trial, and effective cross-examination of the witness by the defense was feasible. United States v. Lopez-Gutierrez, 83 F.3d 1235 (1st Cir. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where armed robbery perpetrators bragged that they were professionals, it was proper to admit as tools of the trade various ski masks, bullets, blue police emergency light, and police uniforms seized from defendants homes. The proof was not unduly prejudicial. United States v. Mojica-Baez, 229 F.3d 292 (1st Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Allegations that a police officer previously attempted to bribe various persons in exchange for dropping charges was properly excluded as modus operandi evidence because the circumstances were not sufficiently idiosyncratic to permit inference of pattern. Treece v. Hochstetler, 213 F.3d 360 (7th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Unless robberies are sufficiently idiosyncratic to make them clearly distinctive from the thousands of other bank robberies committed each year, evidence of the prior crime is nothing more than the character evidence that Rule 404(b) prohibits. United States v. Carroll, 207 F.3d 465 (8th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Expert testimony about drug importation activities was received solely to show the modus operandi of Nigerian heroin importers to give background the jury could consider in assessing defendants version of his activities. United States v. Doe, 149 F.3d 634 (7th Cir. 1998).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of a prior bank robbery one month before the crime charged qualified for admission on the modus operandi theory. United States v. Smith, 103 F.3d 600 (7th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Disparate episodes of abuse did not reflect a signature of unique modus operandi in taking advantage of situations with young children. United States v. LeCompte, 99 F.3d 274 (8th Cir. 1996).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where defendant had several aliases, evidence of a drug transaction after the criminal acts charged found admissible to identify the defendant with the alias used by the person involved in the subsequent drug sale. United States v. Morsley, 64 F.3d 907 (4th Cir. 1995).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Bank robberies by two men wearing ski masks do not constitute distinctive crimes, and thus cannot be used to demonstrate identity. United States v. Luna, 21 F.3d 874 (9th Cir. 1994).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Even where defendant asserted mistaken identity at trial, proof of two other drug sales bracketing time of charge was improper propensity evidence, since the modus operandi was not distinctive and participation in other offenses did not directly address defendants identification in the case on trial. United States v. Carrillo, 981 F.2d 772 (5th Cir. 1993).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prior allegedly similar confrontations with other motorists should not be admitted in an excessive force case against a police officer, given the lack of similar circumstances. Morgan v. City of Marmaduke, 958 F.2d 207 (8th Cir. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of a prior drug transaction involving similar activity by the government and an informant may be admissible to show disputed identity, though the extent to which the government foments the similarity of events may undercut the inference. United States v. Miller, 959 F.2d 1535 (11th Cir. 1992).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 273 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prior altercation between defendant and victim was admissible to prove identity in prosecution for subsequent assault of same person. United States v. Lewis, 780 F.2d 1140 (4th Cir. 1986).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Proving identity is a common purpose for offering evidence of other wrongs. United States v. Ingraham, 832 F.2d 229 (1st Cir. 1987) (defendants other threats to officials admitted to show maker of present threats); United States v. Andiarena, 823 F.2d 673 (1st Cir. 1987) (evidence of similar drug distribution scheme the prior year properly admitted in conspiracy case); United States v. Johnson, 820 F.2d 1065 (9th Cir. 1987); United States v. Paul, 810 F.2d 774 (8th Cir. 1987); United States v. Eggleton, 799 F.2d 378 (8th Cir. 1986); United States v. Lewis, 780 F.2d 1140 (4th Cir. 1986); United States v. Lopez, 800 F.2d 264 (9th Cir. 1986); United States v. Bailleaux, 685 F.2d 1105 (9th Cir. 1982); United States v. Jackson, 714 F.2d 809 (8th Cir. 1983); United States v. Messersmith, 692 F.2d 1315 (11th Cir. 1982).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Defendant need not take the stand to render prior uniquely distinctive events admissible. United States v. Mills, 597 F.2d 693 (9th Cir. 1979).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Intent

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Established Doctrine

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Intent must truly be in issue to justify prior-acts evidence. Lewis v. Velez, 149 F.R.D. 474 (S.D.N.Y. 1993); United States v. Williams, 577 F.2d 188 (2d Cir. 1978).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Intent shown by other crimes must be relevant, necessary, and compatible with Rule 403. United States v. Becham, 582 F.2d 898 (5th Cir. 1978) (en banc); United States v. OConnor, 580 F.2d 38 (7th Cir. 1978).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Other offenses similar to the crime charged, and not unduly remote in time, are admissible to show intent. United States v. Calvert, 523 F.2d 895 (8th Cir. 1975).
