                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When admitted to show intent, the prior acts under Rule 404(b) need not be duplicates, but must be sufficiently similar to support an inference of criminal intent. United States v. Walker, 470 F.3d 1271 (8th Cir. 2006); United States v. Montani, 204 F.3d 761 (7th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        For uncharged-crime evidence sought to be admitted under Rule 404 to be deemed probative of knowledge and intent, the government must identify a similarity or connection between the two acts. United States v. Paulino, 445 F.3d 211 (2d Cir. 2006); United States v. Montani, 204 F.3d 761 (7th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        If an extrinsic act required the same intent as the charged offense and if these acts are proximate in time to the charged offense, then the extrinsic act is highly probative. United States v. Baker, 432 F.3d 1189 (11th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Willfulness may be shown in part by prior acts. United States v. Bergman, 813 F.2d 1027 (9th Cir. 1987); United States v. Gruttadauro, 818 F.2d 1323 (7th Cir. 1987) (harmless error to admit two prior instances of same crime where general intent is required).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        To prevent the admission of bad-acts evidence, a defendants offer to concede knowledge and/or intent issues must: (1) express a clear and unequivocal intention to remove the issue such that, in effect if not in form, it constitutes an offer to stipulate, and (2) the concession must cover the necessary substantive ground to remove the issue from the case. United States v. Lowe, 145 F.3d 45 (1st Cir. 1998).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An extrinsic offense is relevant to the issue of intent only if the offense was in fact committed and the defendant in fact committed it. The proponent of the evidence need not establish these facts by a preponderance of the evidence; rather, the evidence in the case must be sufficient to permit a jury, acting reasonably, to find the preliminary facts by a preponderance of the evidence. United States v. Richards, 204 F.3d 177 (5th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 274 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prior drug trafficking is often held admissible in drug distribution prosecutions on the issue of intent, and evidence of past drug convictions is admissible to prove both knowledge and intent under Rule 404(b) where the accused denies the charged wrongdoing. United States v. Love, 419 F.3d 825 (8th Cir. 2005); United States v. Macedo, 371 F.3d 957 (7th Cir. 2004) (different drugs); United States v. Thomas, 348 F.3d 78 (5th Cir. 2003); United States v. Foster, 344 F.3d 799 (8th Cir. 2003); United States v. Desper, 45 F. Appx 213 (4th Cir. 2002); United States v. Jansen, 218 F. Supp. 2d 659 (M.D. Pa. 2002); United States v. Hill, 249 F.3d 707 (8th Cir. 2001); United States v. Jones, 248 F.3d 671 (7th Cir. 2001); United States v. Parsee, 178 F.3d 374 (5th Cir. 1999); United States v. Ruiz, 178 F.3d 877 (7th Cir. 1999); United States v. Taylor, 1999 U.S. App. LEXIS 19239 (4th Cir. 1999); United States v. Chavez, 119 F.3d 342 (5th Cir. 1997); United States v. Hill, 898 F.2d 72 (7th Cir. 1990); United States v. Robison, 904 F.2d 365 (6th Cir. 1990). But see United States v. Arnold, 467 F.3d 880 (5th Cir. 2006) (intent to distribute intent is not the same intent that Rule 404(b) offers as a legitimate purpose for the introduction of a prior conviction).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Intent in the present case may be shown by prior acts. United States v. Catabran, 836 F.2d 453 (9th Cir. 1988); United States v. Hudson, 843 F.2d 1062 (7th Cir. 1988); United States v. Mora, 845 F.2d 233 (10th Cir. 1988); United States v. Tho-mas, 835 F.2d 219 (9th Cir. 1987) (prior bad check admitted in case where defendant denied intent); Hogan v. AT&T, 812 F.2d 409 (8th Cir. 1987) (prior incident of discrimination, isolated, only weakly probative); United States v. Caputo, 808 F.2d 963 (2d Cir. 1987); United States v. Har-bour, 809 F.2d 384 (7th Cir. 1987); United States v. Paul, 810 F.2d 774 (8th Cir. 1987); United States v. Payne, 805 F.2d 1062 (D.C. Cir. 1986); United States v. Soundingsides, 820 F.2d 1232 (10th Cir. 1987); United States v. Taggatz, 831 F.2d 1355 (7th Cir. 1987); Dial v. Travelers Indem. Co., 780 F.2d 520 (5th Cir. 1986) (arsons of other homes admitted); United States v. Tager, 788 F.2d 349 (6th Cir. 1986); United States v. Hurley, 755 F.2d 788 (11th Cir. 1985); United States v. Kendall, 766 F.2d 1426 (10th Cir. 1985); United States v. Pepe, 747 F.2d 632 (11th Cir. 1984); United States v. Schaffner, 771 F.2d 149 (6th Cir. 1985); United States v. Scott, 767 F.2d 1308 (9th Cir. 1985) (earlier repackaging seizure admitted where defendant denied intent to distribute drugs); United States v. Smith Grading & Paving, 760 F.2d 527 (4th Cir. 1985).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Case Applications

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prior felony drug convictions are relevant and are admissible under Rule 404(b) to show intent and knowledge in a drug prosecution when a defendant makes a general denial defense, which necessarily places the defendants state of mind at issue. Convictions four, ten, and eleven years old are not so remote as to be inadmissible under this rule, and the prior conviction(s) need(s) not involve the same illegal drug(s) as the charged offense. United States v. Banks, 706 F.3d 901 (8th Cir. 2013).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When prior-acts evidence is presented to show intent, similarity is relevant only insofar as the acts are sufficiently alike to support an inference of criminal intent. The prior acts need not be duplicates of the one for which the defendant is now being tried. United States v. Reese, 666 F.3d 1007 (7th Cir. 2012); United States v. Cadet, 664 F.3d 27 (2d Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 414 explicitly allows evidence of prior offenses of child molestation to be considered for its bearing on any matter to which it is relevant. Rule 414(a) thus displaces the usual restriction on propensity evidence embodied in Rule 404(b) and allows the government to offer evidence of a defendants prior sexual misconduct for the purpose of demonstrating the defendants propensity to commit the charged offense. United States v. Sturm, 673 F.3d 1274 (10th Cir. 2012).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a case charging drug possession and distribution, evidence of defendants later, similar crime was admissible to show intent under Rule 404(b). United States v. Davis, 636 F.3d 1281 (10th Cir. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where the purpose for bad-acts evidence under Rule 404(b) is to show intent, the court should consider whether it appeared at the commencement of trial that the defendant would contest the issue of intent, the overall similarity of the charged and extrinsic offenses, and the

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 275 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        temporal proximity between the charged and extrinsic offenses. United States v. Pemberton, 2011 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 61714 (M.D. Ala. 2011).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of prior bad acts could be used under Rule 404(b) to establish a defendants knowledge or intent, both of which were relevant in a prosecution for dealing crack cocaine in light of the defendants testimony that he was loitering at the scene of the drug transaction and that he received twenty dollars of marked currency by panhandling undercover police officers. This type of mere presence defense places a defendants state of mind in question. Moreover, the defendants prior conduct was nearly identical to the offenses with which he was charged in the present case, and he stipulated to the existence of the conviction. Although the prior conduct occurred in 1991, defendant spent many of the intervening years in custodya fact that undercuts any objection to the evidence on the basis of temporal remoteness. Accordingly, the district court did not abuse its discretion in admitting evidence of the defendants prior conviction. United States v. James, 564 F.3d 960 (8th Cir. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Although the line between propensity and intent is a fine one for purposes of a Rule 404(b) analysis, the district court was within its discretion to conclude that a prior drug conviction was relevant to the disputed issues of the defendants knowledge and intent and was admissible to cast doubt on his assertion that he never intended to distribute 10.6 grams of crack that were the basis of the current charge and to shed light on his knowledge of distribution methods for crack cocaine. United States v. Millbrook, 553 F.3d 1057 (7th Cir. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        To meet the test of Rule 404(b), there must be a showing that an issue has been joined as to intent, or another of the 404(b) categories, discrete from a showing of mere propensity. United States v. Millbrook, 553 F.3d 1057 (7th Cir. 2009).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An extrinsic offense relevant to the issue of intent is valid only if an offense was in fact committed and the defendant in fact committed it. Therefore, as a predicate to a determination that the extrinsic offense is relevant and admissible via Rule 404(b), the government must offer proof demonstrating that the defendant committed the offense. If the proof is insufficient, the judge must exclude the evidence because it is irrelevant. United States v. Charles, 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 64655 (W.D. La. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where the issue addressed is the defendants intent to commit the offense charged, the relevancy of the extrinsic offense for purposes of Rule 404(b) derives from the defendants indulging himself in the same state of mind in the perpetration of both the extrinsic and charged offenses. The reasoning is that because the defendant had unlawful intent in the extrinsic offense, it is less likely that he had lawful intent in the present offense. United States v. Charles, 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 64655 (W.D. La. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Past conduct need not be identical to the conduct charged in order for it to be admissible under Rule 404(b), but instead need only be similar enough to be probative of intent. United States v. Snell, 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 77740 (E.D. Pa. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A mere presence defense places the defendants intent directly at issue and thus opens the door to the admission of prior-bad-act evidence under Rule 404(b). This is so because a prior bad act can be probative of intent, in that, if the defendant had an unlawful intent at the time he committed the extrinsic offense, it is as a result less likely that he had a lawful intent when he performed the acts forming the basis of the offense charged in the present case. United States v. Snell, 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 77740 (E.D. Pa. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A past crime is not relevant to intent within the intendment of Rule 402 for purposes of an admissibility analysis under Rule 404(b), unless it required the same form of intent that the government seeks to prove in the current case. United States v. Snell, 2008 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 77740 (E.D. Pa. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Whether evidence of an extrinsic offense subject to analysis under Rule 404(b) is relevant to the issue of intentas opposed to being inadmissible character evidenceis determined by comparing the defendants state of mind in perpetrating the respective offenses. A finding that the offenses involved the same state of mind renders the extrinsic offense relevant to an issue other than character because it lessens the likelihood that the defendant acted with lawful intent in connection with the charged offense. United States v. Crawley, 533 F.3d 349 (5th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 276 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An offer to stipulate intent does not prevent the government from introducing prior acts under 404(b) in order to demonstrate intent. A defendants offer to stipulate to intent to possess heroin, should the jury find that he had in fact possessed heroin in the instant case, does not preclude the government from introducing prior heroin and cocaine trafficking convictions. United States v. Dorsey, 523 F.3d 878 (8th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a bank robbery trial, the defendants prior confessions to two other bank robberies are admissible to rebut the defendants claim that he was not innocently present at during the charged robbery. United States v. Lugo Guerrero, 524 F.3d 5 (1st Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for traveling in interstate commerce for the purpose of engaging in illicit sexual conduct with an individual believed to be a thirteen-year-old girl in violation of 18 U.S.C. 2423(b), and for using a computer, the Internet, and a telephone in attempting to persuade, induce, and entice an individual who has not attained the age of eighteen to engage in illicit sexual activity in violation of 18 U.S.C. 2422(b), images of child pornography found on defendants computer were admissible under Rule 404(b) as evidence of intent to commit the crimes with which he was charged and his predisposition to do so. United States v. Brand, 467 F.3d 179 (2d Cir. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Intent to distribute intent is not the same intent that Rule 404(b) offers as a legitimate purpose for the introduction of a prior conviction. Intent for Rule 404(b) purposes concerns whether a defendant had the requisite state of mind to commit the charged crime, while the crime of possession of a controlled substance with intent to distribute presumes intent to distribute merely from the amount of drugs possessed. United States v. Arnold, 467 F.3d 880 (5th Cir. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Subsequent-acts evidence is particularly relevant when a defendants intent is at issue. United States v. Mares, 441 F.3d 1152 (10th Cir. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where the defendant stipulated to intent and challenged only identity, other-crimes evidence would not be admissible. United States v. Sampson, 385 F.3d 183 (2d Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution of an accounting firm for obstructing a Securities and Exchange Commission proceeding by destroying documents, evidence of recent SEC proceedings against the defendant firm were admissible to show the firms intent. United States v. Arthur Andersen, LLP, 374 F.3d 281 (5th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        On a prosecution for possession with intent to distribute, evidence that the defendant had been arrested before with packets of heroin bearing a certain brand name was admissible by the government to show plan and identity and to rebut the defendants defense of innocence and mistake. United States v. Lattner, 385 F.3d 947 (6th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a trial for various drug offenses related to methamphetamines, evidence that the defendant had been involved in drug sales of a different drug, cocaine, nine years in the past was still admissible to show a necessary element of the crime charged, intent. United States v. Macedo, 371 F.3d 957 (7th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for using the Internet to solicit sex from a minor, evidence that the defendant had, on a prior occasion, used the Internet to solicit sex from a seventeen-year-old (who was not, therefore, a minor according to state law) was admissible in the present case for showing intent and modus operandi even though the prior encounter was legally permissible. United States v. Dhingra, 371 F.3d 557 (9th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Other acts are admissible in an employment discrimination context for the proper purpose of establishing or negating discriminatory intent. Ansell v. Green Acres Contracting Co., 347 F.3d 515 (3d Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a bank fraud prosecution, it was not error to admit extrinsic evidence that defendant did not disclose on a corporate bankruptcy petition that payments were made to insiders within one year of bankruptcy filing; the evidence was relevant to the intent to defraud and refuted defendants claim of mistake or accident. It was not unduly prejudicial, particularly in light of a cautionary instruction given to the jury. United States v. Sanders, 343 F.3d 511 (5th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of false workers compensation claims was admissible in a bank fraud prosecution to prove that defendant acted with intent to defraud and not by mistake or accident, and the prejudicial impact of the evidence was limited by a cautionary jury instruction and by

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 277 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        defendants argument that the government was out to get him for submitting that claim. United States v. Sanders, 343 F.3d 511 (5th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Extrinsic-offense evidence, consisting of a shooting victims testimony that he fled from defendant deputy sheriff because he knew that the deputy had shot another person, was relevant to an issue other than the deputys character, where such evidence of the victims state of mind somewhat helped the government to disprove the deputys main defense; nor did the evidence unduly prejudice the deputy, in that the jury could have believed that the prior shooting was justified, and court gave a limiting instruction. United States v. Williams, 343 F.3d 423 (5th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The shooting victims testimony that he feared that defendant deputy sheriff might plant drugs on him did not violate the rule governing evidence of other crimes, wrongs, or acts, inasmuch as it referred only to the victims unsupported belief, not any other act by the deputy. United States v. Williams, 343 F.3d 423 (5th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Defendants girlfriend was properly permitted to testify that at a relevant time defendant told her that he had been robbing prostitutes customers, and that he would hurt her if she told anyone. Because it was unclear whether this statement related to the particular robberies with which defendant was charged, the government offered the testimony as other crimes evidence under Rule 404(b). The district court properly admitted the statement to prove defendants intent to rob the prostitutes customers and to rebut the suggestion that he was present at the scene of the robberies by mistake or accident. United States v. Pindell, 336 F.3d 1049 (D.C. Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        On the issue of intent, the prosecution in a case against a police officer for unnecessarily releasing a police dog to attack an individual was permitted to prove other, subsequent, episodes where the dog was apparently released without the need to bite and apprehend individuals. United States v. Mohr, 318 F.3d 613 (4th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Letters allegedly sent by a defendant in an extortion conspiracy case to a witness who owed a gambling debt were admissible as corroboration of that witnesss testimony and the defendants admissions to the police about that significant debt. Thus, the letters were probative of defendants intent in agreeing to the conspiracy with another individual. United States v. Boul, 57 F. Appx 35 (3d Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Past trips to purchase drugs in the area from which the charged illegal drug shipment was mailed were probative of a defendants knowledge that the package delivered to her from that area of California contained drugs, and of her intent to receive the package and to distribute its contents. United States v. Mobley, 51 F. Appx 153 (6th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a scheme to commit bank fraud by stealing checks and depositing them in accounts under aliases, evidence of a prior conviction for mail theft was admissible to prove the defendants link to one of the aliases, lack of mistake in taking the mail addressed to the alias, and an inference of criminal intent. United States v. Joseph, 310 F.3d 975 (7th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a false passport prosecution, other falsified identification documents and a passport application were relevant and necessary to establish the defendants identity, his plan to obtain a false passport, and his intent to defraud the government. United States v. Tanouie, 43 F. Appx 568 (4th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A defendants participation in a prior pump and dump securities fraud is admissible in a similar prosecution to show knowledge, intent, and absence of mistake. United States v. Downing, 297 F.3d 52 (2d Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In an illegal firearm possession charge, evidence of two prior illegal gun possessions is admissible because it is relevant to show knowledge of, and intent to possess the firearmsboth elements of the crime. United States v. Cassell, 292 F.3d 788 (D.C. Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for being a felon in possession of a firearm, a prior conviction of illegal possession of a firearm and prior arrest for being a felon in possession of a firearm are not admissible under Rule 404 to show state of mind or intent because the mere intent to possess an illegal weapon differed from that of an individual charged with intent to possess a weapon as a convicted felon; thus defendants prior conviction was irrelevant. United States v. Mosely, 2002 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 6210 (E.D. La. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where defendant was charged with fraudulent telemarketing, proof that he later trained other telemarketers to make misrepresentations was properly received under the rule on the

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 278 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        issue of intent in the defendants prior conduct. United States v. Peterson, 244 F.3d 385 (5th Cir. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In civil rights case charging police officers with use of force, evidence that a defendant previously pulled a chair out from under an exotic dancer as she tried to sit down and then choked her was admissible on the issue of intent where both incidents involved use of police affiliation to as well as disproportionate and violent retribution against persons who did not defer to defendants authority. United States v. Brown, 250 F.3d 580 (7th Cir. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Previous drug sales were admissible despite defendants offer to stipulate the elements of knowledge and intent in a drug distribution case. United States v. Williams, 238 F.3d 871 (7th Cir. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An admission by a drug defendant that he sold cocaine base in the past and knew what it looked like was properly admitted on the issue of intent to distribute cocaine base. United States v. Jones, 255 F.3d 916 (8th Cir. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The relevance of extrinsic-act evidence is a function of its similarity to the offense charged. When the evidence is admitted to show the defendants intent to commit the offense charged, the relevancy of the extrinsic offense derives from the defendants indulging himself in the same state of mind in the perpetration of both the extrinsic and charged offenses. United States v. Richards, 204 F.3d 177 (5th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Defendants urging to another person to make false statements in applying for a loan were admissible to show his intent to influence action by the financial institution. United States v. Hicks, 217 F.3d 1038 (9th Cir. 2000).
