                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where other-crime evidence established the extent of a defendants fraudulent scheme, explained her motive for killing a victim whom she had defrauded, and tended to show her modus operandi, such evidence was relevant to an issue other than the defendants character and was admissible in a prosecution under 18 U.S.C. 1512 for committing

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 301 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        murder to prevent the reporting of her fraudulent acts to law enforcement authorities. United States v. Siegel, 536 F.3d 306 (4th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where other-crimes evidence showed that a defendant was willing to go to shocking lengths to get the money she needed to fuel her gambling addiction, it was in no sense preposterous or unbelievable; thus, it was admissible under Rule 404(b). United States v. Siegel, 536 F.3d 306 (4th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When a defendants defense to a charge of voter fraud is that he was not personally involved in the fraud, evidence that the defendant was connected to other instances of voter fraud is admissible to rebut that defense, as it supports the inference that the defendant was personally involved in the fraud. United States v. Crawley, 533 F.3d 349 (5th Cir. 2008).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Possession of lawful reading material is simply not the type of conduct contemplated by Rule 404(b), and even the possession of lawful reading material containing descriptions of criminal conduct is not similar to actual criminal conduct for purposes of the rule, as there is simply no doubt that a wide gulf separates the act of possessing written descriptions or stories about criminal conduct from the act of committing the offenses described. United States v. Curtin, 489 F.3d 935 (9th Cir. 2007).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        There is no prohibition in Rule 404(b) against using prior-crime evidence for other purposes, such as to demonstrate the implausibility of a defense of coercion. United States v. Dunkin, 438 F.3d 778 (7th Cir. 2006).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a section 1983 case brought by a pretrial detainee, evidence that plaintiff converged on a correctional officer while incarcerated seven years earlier was properly excluded, where the defendants made no offer of proof of the alleged prior incident, the use of the evidence to show a plan on the plaintiffs part would require an improper propensity inference as the evidence was not relevant to plaintiffs state of mind, and the attempt to use plaintiffs prior bad act to show that defendant did not mistakenly or accidentally identify the plaintiff as one of his attackers is nothing more than a ham-fisted attempt to put lipstick on the propensity pig. Surprenant v. Rivas, 424 F.3d 5 (1st Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prior-bad-act evidence involving a prior similar crime was not admissible to show that the defendant was not an innocent pawn of another robber in the commission of the charged offense, since the defendant never claimed he was a pawn in the robbery, but instead proffered an alibi defense. United States v. Owens, 424 F.3d 649 (7th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a case about sham marriages for the purpose of evading immigration laws, evidence of defendants prior acts of soliciting six American women to enter fraudulent marriages with Pakistani men to evade immigration laws was relevant to the defendants intent to commit the charged conduct. These prior bad acts were similar in kind to the crimes charged. There was clear and convincing evidence that the alleged prior acts occurred and these acts were not so inflammatory as to divert the jurys attention from the material issues. Defendant was not prejudiced by the district courts failure to give a separate limiting instruction before each womans testimony. United States v. Anwar, 428 F.3d 1102 (8th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a case charging possession of an unregistered firearm, evidence of defendants terroristic threats to his ex-wife was relevant to his motive and intent in the current prosecution, which also involved his ex-wife, where the prior offense formed part of a history of their relationship. United States v. Walker, 428 F.3d 1165 (8th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that one defendant had appeared on the television programs Crimestoppers and Americas Most Wanted was inadmissible because even if it could be considered inextricably intertwined with evidence regarding the charged offenses (by showing that the fugitive defendant was cognizant of his own guilt), it had virtually no probative value and was unfairly prejudicial. United States v. Baker, 432 F.3d 1189 (11th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A police officers testimony that he had received a complaint from a defendants girlfriend several years earlier claiming that the defendant had beaten her up was inadmissible where the only conceivable probative value of officers testimony was to establish that the defendant did beat up his girlfriend, and was thus more likely to commit the charged crimes. United States v. Baker, 432 F.3d 1189 (11th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An officers testimony that two defendants had been identified in the hospital by a dying victim as the shooters in a prior murder was inadmissible where that murder was

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 302 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        not an uncharged offense arising out of the same transaction or series of transactions as the charged offenses so as to be necessary to complete the story of the charged crimes, nor was it inextricably intertwined with the evidence regarding the charged offenses, but was only relevant to prove defendants bad character and to show their action in conformity therewith. Evidence that a defendant had participated in a murder was properly admitted where the murder was committed during scope of and in furtherance of the charged conspiracy, and was inextricably intertwined with evidence of the conspiracy. United States v. Baker, 432 F.3d 1189 (11th Cir. 2005).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution for possession of cocaine, the defendants prior conviction for possession of marijuana was inadmissible as the government did not articulate a theory of relevance beyond it goes to intent. United States v. Jones, 389 F.3d 753 (7th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a prosecution of sexual abuse of a minor, evidence of conduct between the defendant and two witnesses when they were minors was not admissible as the past conduct did not involve the prosecuting witness, and the only possible inference to draw from the evidence would by the clearly impermissible propensity inference. United States v. Blue Bird, 372 F.3d 989 (8th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In workers compensation claim alleging negligence, the defendant corporation could not introduce evidence of the plaintiffs plea and conviction for beating his girlfriend even though the evidence was proffered for the purpose of showing whether the plaintiff was truly injured. The details of the plea and conviction were not before the court in enough detail to say whether or not they would be probative of this issue. Stovall v. Horizon Offshore Contractors, Inc., 349 F. Supp. 2d 1021 (E.D. La. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a trial for kidnapping and other offenses, evidence of the defendants prior kidnapping crime was not admissible because of its remoteness in time for the charged offense and because it was so similar to the charged offense that a propensity inference could easily arise in the jurys mind. United States v. Mayhew, 337 F. Supp. 2d 1048 (S.D. Ohio 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a trial for providing material support to a foreign terrorist organization, a videotape of Hizballah activities was admissible evidence. Rule 404(b) did not apply because the tape was either direct evidence of the crime charged or evidence of a bad act of the individuals on the videotape and not of the defendant. United States v. Hammoud, 381 F.3d 316 (4th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        When admitting evidence for the purposes of calculating punitive damages, any evidence of recidivist conduct on the part of the defendant must be factually and legally similar to the plaintiffs claim. Here, the district judge could not rely on evidence of racial harassment directed at other employees but not the plaintiff in his calculation of the damage award. Williams v. ConAgra Poultry Co., 378 F.3d 790 (8th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that a government witness operating undercover had been involved in drug transactions supported defense theory that the witness obtained drugs from a source other than the defendant and was framing the defendant. Because it was introduced not to show character but for other purposes under Rule 404(b), the evidence should not have been excluded. United States v. Stephens, 365 F.3d 967 (11th Cir. 2004).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Alias evidence, consisting primarily of documents seized during defendants arrest and of the DEA agents testimony that defendant admitted he used the alias, was not clearly erroneous; the witnesses testified that they knew defendant by his aliases, not by his real name, thus making the use of the alias relevant to the identification of defendant as an organizer of a scheme, and defendant was not prejudiced by the evidence, since he admitted that he used the alias and was allowed to explain the use of that name. United States v. Edwards, 342 F.3d 168 (2d Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of defendants gang involvement had no probative value as to the charge of conspiracy to distribute marijuana. The evidence created the inference of his involvement in a drug conspiracy from his association with a notorious gang. Since the particular gang was well known in the area, this testimony was prejudicial and the district court erred in admitting it. United States v. Wheeler, 67 F. Appx 296 (6th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Proof that a defendant engaged in lawful sexual conduct with males over the age of sixteen was admissible in a case charging intent to engage in unlawful sexual conduct with minor boys. United States v. Long, 328 F.3d 655 (D.C. Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 303 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testimony of an FBI agent as an expert concerning sexual exploitation of children, including the typology, identification, characteristics and strategies of a sexual offender, particularly preferential sex offenders, and the characteristics and behavior of child victims of sexual abuse was not received in error. United States v. Long, 328 F.3d 655 (D.C. Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Proof of a defendants participation in the operation or scheme showed she intended a fraudulent marriage to take place between two individuals, and the prior-bad-acts evidence was offered for the proper purpose of showing intent to aid and abet through a common scheme or plan. United States v. Aguilar, 59 F. Appx 326 (10th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where defendants relied on a claim of self-defense, they were not permitted to introduce evidence of three prior instances of conduct from which the jury could infer that the victim had a violent character and, acting in conformity therewith, started the fight. Under Rule 404(a)(2), specific instances of conduct may be relevant to the subject of character, but Rule 405 establishes the permissible methods of proving character under Rule 404(a)(2). United States v. Herder, 59 F. Appx 257 (10th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        The proximity in time and similarity of circumstances between a defendants firing of the plaintiff and another person militated in favor of admission of the others testimony to prove defendants motive or intent. Plaintiff and the other person were both deputies in the same Sheriffs Department and were fired on the same day. Both men were replaced by defendants election campaign supporters. These similarities warranted the admission of the other act evidence. Whittaker v. Fayette Cnty. Sheriff, 65 F. Appx 387 (3d Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        A threat letter was admissible under Rule 404(b) to show the authors motive for an attack. United States v. Yousef, 327 F.3d 56 (2d Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence concerning state tax returns for the same years as the federal returns involved in a pending case was inextricably intertwined with the offense charged, and not excludable under Rule 404(b). United States v. Peck, 62 F. Appx 561 (6th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that months before the crime defendant was seen wearing an all-black outfit, carrying a shovel and a rifle, might have been taken by a reasonable jury as evidence as probative of the fact that defendant had been planning and preparing for a kidnapping, rape, and murder in the woods, but this is a close call that might better have been avoided by rejecting the evidence as irrelevant. United States v. Jackson, 327 F.3d 273 (4th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where defendant objected at pretrial to use of certain images, he chose to mention them in his own direct testimony. A party introducing evidence cannot complain on appeal that the evidence was erroneously admitted. A defendant may not short circuit the governments right to decide whether to use evidence against the defendant by offering the evidence himself and still preserve its admission as a claim of error on appeal. United States v. Newburn, 58 F. Appx 358 (9th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Testimony that defendant admitted to being involved with a Chicago gang was clearly relevant to the charges, which included the ability to sell guns through connections in Chicago, and four of the guns stolen in Marion were recovered several days later in Chicago by a police gang unit. This evidence, therefore, was relevant, and the district court did not abuse its discretion in admitting it. United States v. Hodges, 315 F.3d 794 (7th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Some courts have expressed serious reservations about whether the possession of drug paraphernalia without evidence of drug trafficking is admissible to show possession of an illegal weapon. Typically, the cases in which this type of evidence is admitted are drug trafficking cases and the evidence is admitted to show the close and well-known connection between firearms and drugs. United States v. Conrad, 320 F.3d 851 (8th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of defendants drug addiction was relevant to establish his motive to commit a charged robbery (in all probability so as to finance his serious drug habit of some five years). Such evidence is permissible under Rule 404(b). United States v. Bitterman, 320 F.3d 723 (7th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of threats by the defendant against a potential witness can be used, if the 403 balancing test is satisfied, to show consciousness of guilt and is admissible under Rule 404(b). United States v. Ramirez-Lopez, 315 F.3d 1143 (9th Cir. 2003).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In an employee discharge case requiring proof of discriminatory intent, for character testimony to be relevant the plaintiff must show that the circumstances involving the other employees

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 304 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        are such that their statements can logically or reasonably be tied to the decision to terminate the plaintiff. A plaintiff can meet this requirement by showing that the same supervisors were involved in prior discriminatory employment actions. The time frame of other alleged acts of discrimination must be carefully considered. Schneider v. City & Cnty. of Denver, 47 F. Appx 517 (10th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of a prior arrest offered to prove that defendant knew tablets found in his bag were pseudoephedrine and could be used to make methamphetamine was not admissible where the testimony provided no logical basis for the jury to infer that defendant possessed the knowledge alleged and no relevance to permit its admission under Rule 404(b). United States v. Sanchez, 47 F. Appx 467 (9th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a charge for sending threatening letters to public officials, unsent threatening letters were admissible under Rule 404(b) as material to the issues of whether the defendants letters were threatening and whether the defendant acted knowingly. United States v. Patzlaff, 44 F. Appx 58 (8th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Without any testimony of particular prior bad acts performed by a defendant with respect to his participation as a gang member, evidence of mere affiliation with a gang does not fall under Rule 404(b) exclusion for other bad acts. United States v. Hodges, 315 F.3d 794 (7th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a police brutality case, testimony from another man arrested by the officer was an impermissible attempt to show that the officer had a propensity to use excessive force and was not relevant to prove the point for which defendant claimed he offered it, the officers intent. Clark v. Martinez, 295 F.3d 809 (8th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        An officers statement that he was conducting robbery surveillance on a defendant constitutes evidence of other crimes, which is inadmissible under Rule 404(b) because of the implication that defendant was under surveillance for other robberies. United States v. Parks, 285 F.3d 1133 (9th Cir. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Rule 404(b) bars evidence of a claim of discrimination by a plaintiff against a previous employer as substantive proof of conduct in conformity therewith. Lovejoy-Wilson v. Noco Motor Fuels, Inc., 242 F. Supp. 2d 236 (W.D.N.Y. 2002).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prior high-speed chase was inadmissible as the charged crimes did not involve a chase, and this evidence was more prejudicial than probative. United States v. Mack, 258 F.3d 548 (6th Cir. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a civil rights suit against a private reform school, allegations that staff members acted inappropriately toward other students on prior occasions were not admissible because of prejudice and confusion, and the fact that the proof would be used to support the inference that defendants acted in conformity with that prior conduct on the occasions in question in the present case. Robert S. v. Stetson Sch., Inc., 256 F.3d 159 (3d Cir. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a fraud case, prior gambling and breaches of contractual duties were not properly admissible under the rule. United States v. Swan, 250 F.3d 495 (7th Cir. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a firearms case, evidence of drug transactions in close proximity, temporally and physically, to the firearms possession, was admissible in support of proof that defendant knowingly possessed weapons. United States v. Thomas, 242 F.3d 1028 (1st Cir. 2001); United States v. Carrasco, 257 F.3d 1045 (9th Cir. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Prior-bad-act evidence is admissible to help the jury understand the basis for the co-conspirators relationship of mutual trust. Committing a crime in anothers presence may show the nature of the trust between the individuals. United States v. Varoudakis, 233 F.3d 113 (1st Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Defendants possession of marijuana and firearms was admissible in an amphetamine distribution prosecution where both drugs were mentioned in key conversations and defendant drew the gun on police when they searched his house. United States v. Jiminez, 224 F.3d 1243 (11th Cir. 2001).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of defendants involvement in two prior uncharged robberies, which were of businesses similar to the one in the charged offense, was proper under Rule 404(b) because it was relevant to his state of mind: his knowledge, intent, planning, and preparation. United States v. Chea, 231 F.3d 531 (9th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        ====== 305 ======

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Where the amounts involved on two prior occasions when defendant possessed crack cocaine similar in the amounts available for distribution, evidence of this conduct was relevant even though the locations differed. United States v. Wash, 231 F.3d 366 (7th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In prosecution of nurse for murder of patients, evidence of her attempted murder of a former husband was excludable as likely to confuse issues and mislead jury even if it might have been relevant, since use of the proof would have required a mini-hearing within the main trial, and the proof was inflammatory. United States v. Gilbert, 229 F.3d 15 (1st Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Neighbors statements that on two prior occasions she smelled an odor similar to the one that came from defendants apartment on the day he was arrested were admissible on charges of manufacturing methamphetamine in the apartment regularly. United States v. Morales Cervantes, 219 F.3d 882 (9th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence that defendant gave a person a gun and discussed robbing a liquor store and killing the owner was properly received to show access to a gun and the existence of a plan. United States v. Paul, 217 F.3d 989 (8th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        Evidence of a companys alleged fabrication of performance problems in relation to one former employees dismissal offered on the inference that the company was likely to have fabricated customer complaints and other performance problems in the instant case is the very evil that Rule 404(b) seeks to prevent. Becker v. Arco Chem. Co., 207 F.3d 176 (3d Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        In a spousal assault case, defendants prior assaults on his wife had no relationship to any issues in the case. Alleged prior assaults committed in 1997 and 1985 were in fact offered to demonstrate bad character, and should, therefore, not have been admitted. United States v. Chavez, 204 F.3d 1305 (11th Cir. 2000).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        While the government may not attempt to prove a defendants guilt by showing that the defendant associates with unsavory characters, evidence of the defendants own prior conduct is not barred by this doctrine. United States v. Richards, 204 F.3d 177 (5th Cir. 2000).
